z:row.TitlePrimary: Lessons learned from recent D-3He Tokamak power reactor studies
z:row.TitleSecondary: Fusion Facilities Planning for the 1990s, 25-26 June 1991
z:row.Keyword: deuterium|fusion reactor fuel|fusion reactor ignition|fusion reactor theory and design|helium
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Previous studies have described progress in the design of D-T tokamak reactors. The author addresses only the lessons that have been learned in the design of D-3He tokamak reactors. Unlike the previous work, scientists and engineers have only been working on advanced fueled tokamak reactors for only a short time. Therefore one should expect that the rate of progress in the future may be higher for the D-3He systems than for the D-T
z:row.User2: Tokamak power reactor studies; advanced fueled tokamak reactors; D-3He; D-T

z:row.TitlePrimary: Projected ranges of energetic ions in solids
z:row.Keyword: Solids -- Radiation Effects|Ions|Materials - Ion Implantation
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Projected range equations, including nuclear and electronic energy losses up to the third moment, are derived as a simple and accurate means to evaluate projected ranges of energetic ions in solids. With the proposed expressions for the nuclear stopping cross section and the third-moment of both nuclear and electronic energy losses, good agreement is observed between the calculated results and experimental data for the projected ranges of ions in both single- and multi-component target materials.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Electronic Energy Losses; Ion Ranges

z:row.TitlePrimary: Phase stability of a manganese-stabilized low-activation martensitic steel
z:row.TitleSecondary: Fourth International Conference on Fusion Reactor Materials (ICFRM-4), 4-8 Dec. 1989
z:row.Keyword: ageing|crystal microstructure|fusion reactor materials|martensitic steel|neutron effects|phase equilibrium
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Fusion Technol. Inst., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The development of alloys with reduced long-life radioactivity has been incorporated into the goals of fusion materials development. One possible candidate alloy is an Fe-12Cr-6.5Mn-1W-0.3V-0.1C stabilized martensitic steel. The phase stability of this steel has been investigated following neutron irradiation over a temperature range of 420 to 600°C to doses as high as 100 dpa. The microstructural response of the irradiated steel has been compared to that of the same alloy aged for 10000 h from 365 to 600°C. M23C6 was the only carbide found in both the aged and irradiated structures. In the samples aged at 420 and 520°C, and the samples irradiated at 520°C, an Fe-Cr-Mn-W chi-phase formed. In the samples irradiated at 420°C, alpha prime formed. The presence of chi-phase in both the thermally aged and neutron irradiated steels indicates that the Fe-Cr-Mn system is prone to intermetallic phase formation so that careful study of the effects of alloying are needed
z:row.User2: low-activation martensitic steel; long-life radioactivity; fusion materials; phase stability; neutron irradiation; microstructural response; M23C6; irradiated structures; thermally aged; intermetallic phase formation; 365 to 600 degC; 10000 h

z:row.TitlePrimary: Effect of tempering and aging on a low activation martensitic steel
z:row.TitleSecondary: 75th Anniversary World Materials Congress on Irradiation-Enhanced Materials Science and Engineering, Sep 25-29 1988
z:row.Keyword: Steel metallography|Martensite|Radiation effects|Tempering|Aging of materials|Neutrons|Composition|Characterization|Metallographic phases|Transmission electron microscopy|Carbides
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Metallurgical Transactions A (Physical Metallurgy and Materials Science)
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Tempering and aging studies were carried out on a martensitic stainless steel which was designed to have reduced long-life activation after exposure to neutrons. Nickel, molybdenum, and niobium additions were restricted in these low activation alloys. The composition of the steel in weight percent was 12 pct Cr, 0.1 pct C, 0.3 pct V, 0.9 pct W, 6.4 pct Mn, and 0.1 pct Si, where manganese is used to stabilize the steel against delta ferrite and tungsten is used for tempering resistance. The tempering conditions studied were 2 hours at 400 °C, 500 °C, 600 °C, 700 °C, 800 °C, and 900 °C and 24 hours at 500 °C and 700 °C. The steel was aged for 1000 and 5000 hours at 365 °C, 420 °C, 520 °C, and 600 °C. Microhardness, optical metallography, and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) were used to characterize the samples. The results indicated that the Ac1 in this steel lies between 700 °C and 800 °C. During the 2-hour tempers at 400 °C and 500 °C, M3C formed. After 24 hours at 500 °C, the M3C was starting to be replaced by M23C6. At higher tempering temperatures and in all the aged samples, M23C6 was the only carbide found. A manganese-rich chi phase was also seen in the samples aged at 420 °C and 520 °C.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Low activation martensitic steel; Microhardness; Optical metallography; Chi phase

z:row.TitlePrimary: Effects of preinjected helium in heavy-ion irradiated nickel and nickel-copper alloys
z:row.TitleSecondary: 75th Anniversary World Materials Congress on Irradiation-Enhanced Materials Science and Engineering, Sep 25-29 1988
z:row.Keyword: Nickel alloys|Nickel|Radiation effects|Ions|Helium|Crystal lattices|Crystal defects|Transmission electron microscopy
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Metallurgical Transactions A (Physical Metallurgy and Materials Science)
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Pure nickel and two nickel-copper alloys (Ni-10 at. pct Cu and Ni-50 at. pct Cu) containing 50 appm preinjected helium have been irradiated with 14 MeV nickel ions at a constant homologous temperature of 0.45 Tm to 3 to 5 dpa at a depth of 1 μm from the surface. The radiation-induced lattice defects have been analyzed by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) with samples prepared in cross section. In the helium preinjected region of the pure nickel specimen, a substantial density of voids with an average diameter of 35 nm was observed. The nickel-copper alloys were found to contain only a high density of small helium bubbles (under 5 nm in diameter) and dislocation loops. The density of both dislocation loops and helium bubbles increases with increasing copper content, while the size decreases. The observed resistance of the nickel-copper alloys to void formation regardless of the presence of helium bubbles is considered to be the result of local clustering of like atoms which generates a high density of traps, and, thereby, disperses vacancies and gas atoms.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Helium preinjection; Heavy ion irradiation; Local clustering; Void formation; Nickel copper alloys; Copper content; Helium bubbles

z:row.TitlePrimary: Mining helium-3 from the moon. A solution to the earth's energy needs in the 21st century
z:row.TitleSecondary: Advanced Materials - Application of Mineral and Metallurgical Processing Principles, Feb 26-Mar 1 1989
z:row.Keyword: Helium|Moon|Nuclear Fuels
z:row.Publisher: Publ by Soc of Mining Engineers of AIME, Littleton, CO, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The recent discovery of large amounts of helium-3, a valuable thermonuclear fuel, on the surface of the Moon has prompted engineers and scientists to examine the commercial attractiveness, technological feasibility, and environmental features of this resource. The main feature of this fuel cycle is the low ( approximately equals 1%) fraction of energy released in neutrons. Such low neutron fluxes result in important reductions in the amount of radioactivity, afterheat, and radiation damage in a fusion power plant. On the other hand, the high fraction of energy in charged particles and synchrotron radiation can be directly converted to electricity, resulting in high efficiencies of electricity production ( approximately equals 60-70%). It has been shown that there is 10 times more energy is He3 on the Moon than there ever was in fossil fuels (i.e., coal, oil, and gas) on Earth. The techniques and equipment needed to extract the helium-3 have been examined and internationally acceptable mechanisms for the industrial development of this resource have been outlined. This paper expands on the financial, environmental, and technical aspects of the recovery of helium-3 for use in the 21st century.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Lunar Mining; Moon Mining

z:row.TitlePrimary: SIRIUS-T, a symmetrically illuminated ICF tritium production facility
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings, IEEE Thirteenth Symposium on Fusion Engineering (Cat. No.89CH2820-9), 2-6 Oct. 1989
z:row.TitleTertiary: Proceedings, IEEE Thirteenth Symposium on Fusion Engineering (Cat. No.89CH2820-9)
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor theory and design|tritium handling
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Fusion Technol. Inst., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A scoping study of a symmetrically illuminating inertial confinement fusion (ICF) tritium production facility utilizing a KrF laser is presented. A single-shell ICF target is illuminated by 92 beams symmetrically distributed around a spherical cavity filled with xenon gas at 1.0 torr. The driver energy and target gain are taken to be 2 MJ and 50, respectively, for the optimistic case, and 1 MJ and 100, respectively, for the conservative case. Based on a graphite dry wall evaporation rate of 0.1 cm/yr for a 100-MJ yield, a cavity radius of 3.5 m for a repetition rate of 10 Hz and 3.0 m for 5 Hz is estimated. A spherical structural frame capable of supporting 92 blanket modules, each with a beam port in the center, has been scoped out. The authors have selected liquid lithium in vanadium structure as the primary breeding concept, utilizing beryllium as a neutron multiplier. A tritium breeding ratio of 1.83 can be achieved in the 3-m radius cavity, which at 10 Hz and an availability of 75% provides an annual tritium surplus of 32.6 kg. Assuming 100% debt financing over a 30-yr reactor lifetime, the production cost of T2 for the 2-MJ driver case is $7325/g for a 5% interest rate, and $12370/g for a 10% interest rate
z:row.User2: SIRIUS-T; scoping study; symmetrically illuminating inertial confinement fusion; single-shell ICF target; driver energy; target gain; graphite dry wall evaporation; spherical structural frame; primary breeding concept; neutron multiplier

z:row.TitlePrimary: US aqueous salt blanket for ITER
z:row.Keyword: corrosion|electrolysis|fusion reactor materials|fusion reactor safety|fusion reactor theory and design|radiolysis
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Fusion Technol. Inst., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Aqueous lithium salt blankets have some very attractive features which make them likely candidates for use in the next generation of fusion devices such as ITER and beyond. The main attraction derives from the fact that such a blanket can go from a non-tritium-breeding state to a tritium breeding state by the simple dissolution of a lithium salt into the cooling water. Such a blanket is also relatively simple to design and analyze, and is amenable to accommodating penetrations. On the other hand, the salt solution raises concern with respect to radiolysis, electrolysis and corrosion, as well as safety issues related to them. The authors describe the design of the US entry of an aqueous salt blanket for ITER
z:row.User2: radiolysis; electrolysis; corrosion; safety; design; aqueous salt blanket; ITER; aqueous Li salt blanket

z:row.TitlePrimary: Computer simulation of ion beam mixing
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the Ninth International Conference on Ion Beam Analysis, Jun 26-30 1989
z:row.Keyword: Radiation Effects -- Computer Simulation|Ion Beams|Diffusion
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Nuclear Instruments & Methods in Physics Research, Section B: Beam Interactions with Materials and Atoms
z:row.PeriodicalAbbrev: Nucl Instrum Methods Phys Res Sect B
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A highly optimized dynamic Monte Carlo program TAMIX has been developed to simulate the ion beam mixing process. In addition to the collisional features, some of the diffusional processes are taken into account in TAMIX for elevated temperature irradiation applications. TAMIX can be run in three modes, i.e. Static mode, collisional dynamic mode, and collisional-diffusional dynamic mode. TAMIX is a non-analog vectorized Monte Carlo program for the full use of the capability of vector computers such as the Cray. In TAMIX, sophisticated models have been adopted to obtain both speed and accuracy, including tabulation of the scattering angles, energy-dependent mean free path for nuclear collisions, 'random surface model' for sputtering, and concentration-dependent surface binding energies. The simulation results applied to a wide range of situations show good agreement with experimental data.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Software Package TAMIX; Ion Beam Mixing

z:row.TitlePrimary: An aqueous lithium salt blanket for ITER
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings, IEEE Thirteenth Symposium on Fusion Engineering (Cat. No.89CH2820-9), 2-6 Oct. 1989
z:row.TitleTertiary: Proceedings, IEEE Thirteenth Symposium on Fusion Engineering (Cat. No.89CH2820-9)
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor materials|fusion reactor safety|lithium compounds|Tokamak devices
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Fusion Technol. Inst., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: An aqueous lithium salt blanket is designed as a candidate for the tritium production blanket of ITER (International Thermonuclear Experimental Reactor). There are two rows of flat tube aqueous salt flow channels placed between beryllium blocks. The inboard and outboard blanket configurations have been optimized to maximize tritium breeding. A local outboard TBR (tritium breeding ratio) of 1.44 is obtained using LiOH at a concentration of 5 g/100 cm3. The overall TBR determined from 3-D neutronics calculations is 0.88. The aqueous-salt flow parameters have been optimized to minimize the salt pressure and inventory, leading to a pressure of 1.15 MPa and tritium inventory of 104 g. There are no crevices in the aqueous-salt channels, and a redundancy has been provided against a salt-to-water leak potential. The first wall, blanket, and shield qualify for shallow land burial. The highest temperature in the blanket after a two-week period without coolant is only 440°C. The first wall and blanket are capable of withstanding the worst disruption load
z:row.User2: aqueous lithium salt blanket; ITER; International Thermonuclear Experimental Reactor; flat tube aqueous salt flow channels; salt-to-water leak potential; shallow land burial; LiOH; T2 inventory

z:row.TitlePrimary: Apollo-L2, an advanced fuel tokamak reactor utilizing direct conversion
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings, IEEE Thirteenth Symposium on Fusion Engineering (Cat. No.89CH2820-9), 2-6 Oct. 1989
z:row.TitleTertiary: Proceedings, IEEE Thirteenth Symposium on Fusion Engineering (Cat. No.89CH2820-9)
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor materials|fusion reactor theory and design|radiation effects|Tokamak devices
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Fusion Technol. Inst., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A scoping study of a tokamak reactor fueled by a D-3He plasma is presented. The Apollo D-3He tokamak incorporates recent advances in high-field magnets (20 T) and utilizes rectennas to convert the synchrotron radiation directly to electricity. The low neutron wall loading (0.1 MW/m2) permits a first wall lasting the life of the plant and enables the reactor to be classified as inherently safe. The cost of electricity is less than that from a similar power level D-T reactor. Technology considerations, including heat flux considerations, reference technology, and radiation damage to structural materials are discussed
z:row.User2: electricity cost; Apollo-L2; advanced fuel tokamak; direct conversion; scoping study; high-field magnets; rectennas; neutron wall loading; first wall; inherently safe; heat flux; reference technology; radiation damage; structural materials; 20 T; D-3He plasma

z:row.TitlePrimary: LIBRA-a light ion beam inertial confinement fusion reactor conceptual design
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor theory and design
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin University Fusion Technol. Inst., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The LIBRA light ion beam fusion commercial reactor study is a self-consistent conceptual design of a 330 MWe power plant with an accompanying economic analysis. Fusion targets are imploded by 4 MJ shaped pulses of 30 MeV Li ions at a rate of 3 Hz. The target gain is 80, leading to a yield of 320 MJ. The high intensity part of the ion pulse is delivered by 16 diodes through 16 separate z-pinch plasma channels formed in 100 torr of helium with trace amounts of lithium. The blanket is an array of porous flexible silicon carbide tubes with Li17Pb83 flowing downward through them. These tubes (INPORT units) shield the target chamber wall from both neutron damage and the shock overpressure of the target explosion. The target chamber is a right circular cylinder, 8.7 meters in diameter. The target chamber is `self-pumped' by the target explosion generated overpressure into a surge tank partially filled with liquid that surrounds the target chamber. This scheme refreshes the chamber at the desired 3 Hz frequency without excessive pumping demands. The blanket multiplication is 1.2 and the tritium breeding ratio is 1.4. The direct capital cost of LIBRA is estimated to be $2200/kWe
z:row.User2: fusion target implosion; porous flexible tube; self-pumping; light ion beam inertial confinement fusion reactor; conceptual design; LIBRA; commercial reactor; economic analysis; target gain; yield; z-pinch plasma channels; INPORT units; target chamber wall; neutron damage; shock overpressure; right circular cylinder; surge tank; blanket multiplication; breeding ratio; direct capital cost; 4 MJ; 30 MeV; 3 Hz; 100 torr; 8.7 m; Li17Pb83; He-Li; SiC; T

z:row.TitlePrimary: Mechanical property changes in ion-irradiated metals. Part II. High-strength Cu-Ni-Be alloy
z:row.TitleSecondary: Symposium on Irradiation-Enhanced Materials Science and Engineering - as part of the 1988 World Materials Congress, Sep 25-29 1988
z:row.Keyword: Copper Nickel Beryllium Alloys -- Radiation Effects|Copper Metallography--Microstructures
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Metallurgical Transactions A (Physical Metallurgy and Materials Science)
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Mechanical property changes in a high-strength copper alloy as a result of 14-MeV Cu ion irradiation have been investigated using a recently developed mechanical properties microprobe (MPM). A Cu-1.5 pct Ni-0.3 pct Be alloy was irradiated in both the cold-worked and aged and solution-annealed and aged conditions to a peak damage dose of 40 displacements per atom (dpa) (10 dpa at 1 μm) over the temperature range of 100°C to 500°C. Ultra-low load micro-indentation hardness changes were measured parallel to the ion beam and perpendicular to the beam, the latter by cross-sectional techniques. Both thermal and radiation-enhanced softening was observed in the cold-worked and aged material. The amount of softening increased as temperature increased. Irradiation had little effect on the solution-annealed and aged material, and only at 500°C was any thermally induced softening observed.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Mechanical Property Changes; Thermal Softening; Radiation Hardening

z:row.TitlePrimary: Radiation damage and copper distribution in 14 MeV copper-ion-implanted nickel - TEM and AEM analyses in cross-section
z:row.TitleSecondary: Surfaces and Interfaces: Proceedings of the Second Conference on Frontiers of Electron Microscopy in Materials Science, May 16-19 1988
z:row.Keyword: Nickel and Alloys -- Radiation Damage|Copper and Alloys|Microscopic Examination--Transmission Electron Microscopy|Spectroscopy, Auger Electron|Nuclear Reactors, Fusion--Materials
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: 14 Mev Cu ions have been implanted into a pure Ni specimen at 500°C to a dose of 6×1020 ions/m2. TEM and AEM analyses were performed in cross-section to investigate the effect of implanted Cu on the formation of defect clusters. The TEM result has been compared with that obtained in another Ni specimen which was irradiated with 14 Mev Ni ions to the same damage level at the same temperature. While voids formed throughout the entire damage range in the Ni ion-irradiated sample, they mainly appeared at the near-surface region and at the peak damage depth in the Cu-ion-implanted specimen. A high density of dislocation loops formed in the region where implanted Cu ions were detected by AEM. The AEM result of the implanted Cu concentration profile has been compared with a Monte Carlo calculation.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Depth Profiles; Analytical Electron Microscopy (AEM); Dislocation Loops

z:row.TitlePrimary: Apollo-an advanced fuel fusion power reactor for the 21st century
z:row.TitleSecondary: Eighth Topical Meeting on the Technology of Fusion Energy, 9-13 Oct. 1988
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor theory and design|Tokamak devices
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A preconceptual design of a tokamak reactor fueled by a D-He-3 plasma is presented. A low aspect ratio (A=2-4) device is studied here but high aspect ratio devices (A>6) may also be quite attractive. The Apollo D-He-3 tokamak capitalizes on recent advances in high field magnets (20 T) and utilizes rectennas to convert the synchrotron radiation directly to electricity. The overall efficiency ranges from 37 to 52% depending on whether the bremsstrahlung energy is utilized. The low neutron wall loading (0.1 MW/m2) allows a permanent first wall to be designed and the low nuclear decay heat enables the reactor to be classed as inherently safe. The cost of electricity from Apollo is >40% lower than electricity from a similar sized DT reactor
z:row.User2: advanced fuel fusion power reactor; preconceptual design; tokamak reactor; low aspect ratio; high aspect ratio devices; Apollo; high field magnets; synchrotron radiation; D-3He fuelled reactor

z:row.TitlePrimary: Cross-section specimen preparation technique for nickel alloys and stainless steels
z:row.TitleSecondary: Surfaces and Interfaces: Proceedings of the Second Conference on Frontiers of Electron Microscopy in Materials Science, May 16-19 1988
z:row.Keyword: Nickel and Alloys -- Electroplating|Stainless Steel|Microscopic Examination--Transmission Electron Microscopy|Radiation Damage
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A reliable and repeatable procedure for electroplating nickel on nickel- and iron-based alloys has been developed. The plating bath electrolyte is a modified Wood nickel solution. The addition of a biological detergent to the electrolyte yields a non-porous plating layer. The application of a low plating current along with moderately intense agitation of the electrolyte results in a strong interfacial bond between the irradiated foil and the plated nickel. The strength of this interfacial bond determines the quality of the electron-transparent thin area that is obtainable. Successful plating has been achieved with ion-irradiated pure Fe-Ni-Cr ternary, nickel, Ni-Cu binaries, US Prime Candidate Alloy (PCA), and Soviet EP-838 stainless steel. An unirradiated low-activation ferritic steel has also been successfully plated. An electron-transparent thin area is achieved by two-step twin-jet electropolishing, supplemented by ion sputtering. Micrographs of several irradiated alloys displayed in cross-section using this technique are presented.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Specimen Preparation; Prime Candidate Alloy; Stainless Steel EP-838

z:row.TitlePrimary: Advances in commercial ICF technology since 1986
z:row.TitleSecondary: Eighth Topical Meeting on the Technology of Fusion Energy, 9-13 Oct. 1988
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor theory and design
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Progress in the march toward commercial ICF fusion reactors has been uneven in the past few years. Considerable advances have been made in the area of light ion beam fusion through the development of rep ratable drivers (i.e. HERMES-III technology) and diodes (i.e. applied B configuration with renewable Li surfaces). Significant progress in the development of lasers to compress targets has also been made through the KrF Aurora program. The possibility of lowering the cost of glass in the advanced solid state lasers has been given serious consideration. The development of the induced spatial incoherence (ISI) technique to improve the uniformity of the laser beam has allowed physicists and engineers to once again contemplate the use of symmetric illumination. This would reduce the driver energy required to achieve high gains but it also introduces difficulty in the reactor design
z:row.User2: inertial confinement; ICF technology; fusion reactors; light ion beam; rep ratable drivers; HERMES-III; diodes; B configuration; Aurora program; glass; solid state lasers; induced spatial incoherence; symmetric illumination; driver energy; reactor design; Li; KrF

z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Fusion Technol Inst, Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A scoping study of a tokamak reactor fueled by a D-3He plasma is presented. The Apollo D-3He tokamak incorporates recent advances in high-field magnets (20 T) and utilizes rectennas to convert the synchrotron radiation directly to electricity. The low neutron wall loading (0.1 MW/m2) permits a first wall lasting the life of the plant and enables the reactor to be classified as inherently safe. The cost of electricity is less than that from a similar power level D-T reactor. Technology considerations, including heat flux considerations, reference technology, and radiation damage to structural materials are discussed.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Apollo-L2 Tokamak Reactor

z:row.TitlePrimary: An aqueous lithium salt self-cooled blanket and shield for ITER
z:row.TitleSecondary: Eighth Topical Meeting on the Technology of Fusion Energy, 9-13 Oct. 1988
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor materials|fusion reactor theory and design|lithium compounds
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A low cost low risk tritium breeding concept has been developed for ITER. This concept is based on dissolving lithium compounds in the water coolant. This makes it possible to breed tritium in all the shield zones, and results in tritium self-sufficiency as well as enhanced magnetic protection. The design that maximizes the outboard tritium breeding ratio utilizes a 40 cm thick zone of Be balls followed by an 80 cm thick zone of steel balls. Single size balls are used to minimize the pressure drop. The overall TBR excluding tritium bred in the test modules is 1.1. The inlet coolant temperature is 40°C and the temperature rise is 15°C in the first wall and 35°C in the blanket
z:row.User2: self-cooled blanket; low risk tritium breeding concept; ITER; water coolant; shield zones; tritium self-sufficiency; steel balls; Be balls; T breeding; aqueous LiOH; aqueous LiNO3

z:row.TitlePrimary: Possibilities for breakeven and ignition of D-3He fusion fuel in a near term tokamak
z:row.Keyword: deuterium|fusion reactor fuel|fusion reactor ignition|fusion reactor theory and design|helium|neutron spectra|plasma heating|plasma toroidal confinement|shielding
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Fusion Power Associates, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The feasibility of D-3He reactor plasma conditions in a tokamak of the NET/INTOR class is investigated. It is found that, depending on the energy confinement scaling law, energy breakeven can be achieved in NET without significant modification of its design. Significant improvement in Q (ratio of fusion power to injected power) can be achieved by removing the tritium producing blanket and replacing the inboard neutron shield by a thinner shield optimized for the neutron spectrum in D-3He; this allows the plasma major radius and aspect ratio to be reduced and higher beta and Q-values (up to about 3) to be achieved. The implications of D-3He operation for neutron shielding, the heat loads on the first wall and the divertor as well as plasma refuelling are considered
z:row.User2: INTOR; fusion reactor; breakeven; ignition; fusion fuel; tokamak; reactor plasma; energy confinement scaling law; NET; blanket; inboard neutron shield; neutron spectrum; major radius; aspect ratio; beta; Q-values; heat loads; first wall; divertor; plasma refuelling; D-3He

z:row.TitlePrimary: SIRIUS-T, a symmetrically illuminated ICF tritium production facility
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings - IEEE Thirteenth Symposium on Fusion Engineering Part 2 (of 2), Oct 2-6 1989
z:row.Keyword: Inertial Confinement Fusion -- Design|Tritium--Production|Laser Beams--Applications|Beryllium and Alloys|Neutrons
z:row.Publisher: Publ by IEEE, Piscataway, NJ, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Fusion Technol Inst, Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A scoping study of a symmetrically illuminating inertial confinement fusion (ICF) tritium production facility utilizing a KrF laser is presented. A single-shell ICF target is illuminated by 92 beams symmetrically distributed around a spherical cavity filled with xenon gas at 1.0 torr. The driver energy and target gain are taken to be 2 MJ and 50, respectively, for the optimistic case, and 1 MJ and 100, respectively, for the conservative case. Based on a graphite dry wall evaporation rate of 0.1 cm/yr for a 100-MJ yield, a cavity radius of 3.5 m for a repetition rate of 10 Hz and 3.0 m for 5 Hz is estimated. A spherical structural frame capable of supporting 92 blanket modules, each with a beam port in the center, has been scoped out. The authors have selected liquid lithium in vanadium structure as the primary breeding concept, utilizing beryllium as a neutron multiplier. A tritium breeding ratio of 1.83 can be achieved in the 3-m radius cavity, which at 10 Hz and an availability of 75% provides an annual tritium surplus of 32.6 kg. Assuming 100% debt financing over a 30-yr reactor lifetime, the production cost of T2 for the 2-MJ driver case is $7,325/g for a 5% interest rate, and $12,370/g for a 10% interest rate.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

This makes it possible to breed tritium in all the shield zones, and results in tritium self-sufficiency as well as enhanced magnet protection. The design that maximizes the outboard tritium breeding ratio utilizes a 40 cm thick zone of Be balls followed by an 80 cm thick zone of steel balls. Single size balls are used to minimize the pressure drop. The overall TBR excluding tritium bred in the test modules is 1.1. The inlet coolant temperature is 40°C and the temperature rise is 15°C in the first wall and 35°C in the blanket.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Libra-A light ion beam fusion reactor conceptual design
z:row.TitleSecondary: International School of Plasma Physics `Piero Caldirola'. Inertial Confinement Fusion. Proceedings of the Course and Workshop, 6-16 Sept. 1988
z:row.TitleTertiary: International School of Plasma Physics `Piero Caldirola'. Inertial Confinement Fusion. Proceedings of the Course and Workshop
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor theory and design|ion beams
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Fusion Technol. Inst., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The LIBRA light ion beam fusion commercial reactor study is a self-consistent conceptual design of a 330 MWe power plant with an accompanying economic analysis. Fusion targets are imploded by 4-MJ-shaped pulses of 30 MeV Li ions at a rate of 3 Hz. The target gain is 80, leading to a yield of 320 MJ. The high intensity part of the ion pulse is delivered by 16 diodes through 16 separate z-pinch plasma channels formed in 100 torr of helium with trace amounts of lithium. The blanket is an array of porous flexible silicon carbide tubes with Li17Pb83 flowing downward through them. These tubes (INPORT units) shield the target chamber wall from both neutron damage and the shock overpressure of the target explosion. The target chamber is a right circular cylinder, 8.7 meters in diameter. The target chamber is `self-pumped' by the target explosion generated overpressure into a surge tank partially filled with liquid that surrounds the target chamber. This scheme refreshes the chamber at the desired 3 Hz frequency without excessive pumping demands. The blanket multiplication is 1.2 and the tritium breeding ratio is 1.4. The direct capital cost of LIBRA is estimated to be $2200/kWe
z:row.User2: fusion target implosion; shaped pulses; porous flexible tube array; Libra-A light ion beam fusion reactor; conceptual design; commercial reactor; power plant; economic analysis; target gain; yield; z-pinch plasma channels; blanket; INPORT units; target chamber wall; neutron damage; shock overpressure; target explosion; right circular cylinder; surge tank; multiplication; direct capital cost; 4 MJ; 30 MeV; 3 Hz; 320 MJ; 100 torr; 8.7 m; Li ions; Li17Pb83; He-Li; SiC; T breeding ratio

z:row.TitlePrimary: Aqueous lithium salt blanket for ITER
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings - IEEE Thirteenth Symposium on Fusion Engineering Part 1 (of 2), Oct 2-6 1989
z:row.Keyword: Nuclear Reactors, Fusion -- Breeding Blankets|Tritium--Production|Salts|Lithium Compounds|Neutrons
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Fusion Technol Inst, Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: An aqueous lithium salt blanket is designed as a candidate for the tritium production blanket of ITER (International Thermonuclear Experimental Reactor). There are two rows of flat tube aqueous salt flow channels placed between beryllium blocks. The inboard and outboard blanket configurations have been optimized to maximize tritium breeding. A local outboard TBR (tritium breeding ratio) of 1.44 is obtained using LiOH at a concentration of 5 g/100 cm3. The overall TBR determined from 3-D neutronics calculations is 0.88. The aqueous-salt flow parameters have been optimized to minimize the salt pressure and inventory, leading to a pressure of 1.15 MPa and tritium inventory of 104 g. There are no crevices in the aqueous-salt channels, and a redundancy has been provided against a salt-to-water leak potential. The first wall, blanket, and shield qualify for shallow land burial. The highest temperature in the blanket after a two-week period without coolant is only 440°C. The first wall and blanket are capable of withstanding the worst disruption load.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: ITER (International Thermonuclear Experimental Reactor)

z:row.TitlePrimary: Transition to environmentally acceptable fuels in the 21st century
z:row.TitleSecondary: Emerging Nuclear Energy Systems 1989, ICENES '89. Proceedings of the Fifth International Conference, 3-6 July 1989
z:row.TitleTertiary: Emerging Nuclear Energy Systems 1989, ICENES '89. Proceedings of the Fifth International Conference
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor theory and design|plasma confinement
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Fusion Technol. Inst., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The D/3He fusion fuel cycle merits consideration because of its benign environmental impact and the possibility of utilizing the large lunar 3He resource in the 21st century. Preconceptual designs of low beta, low aspect ratio tokamaks have been studied. Sufficient terrestrial sources of 3He are available to operate fusion research and Power Demonstration programs through the year 2020
z:row.User2: low beta tokamaks; D/3He fusion fuel cycle; lunar 3He resource; low aspect ratio tokamaks

z:row.TitlePrimary: Breakeven and ignition conditions for D-3He fusion
z:row.TitleSecondary: Emerging Nuclear Energy Systems 1989, ICENES '89. Proceedings of the Fifth International Conference, 3-6 July 1989
z:row.TitleTertiary: Emerging Nuclear Energy Systems 1989, ICENES '89. Proceedings of the Fifth International Conference
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor fuel|fusion reactor ignition|fusion reactor theory and design|plasma confinement
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Fusion Power Associates, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Although there are only small amounts of 3He available on Earth, studies on the D-3He reaction do exist in the literature assuming that sufficient quantities of 3He can be produced by radioactive decay of Tritium which would have to be bred with Lithium. The recent realization that the moon contains a large amount of the isotope 3He has rekindled interest in the D-3He fuel cycle. In this paper the main results of a study sponsored by KfK and pursued in cooperation with scientists of the University of Madison, USA, to quantify breakeven and if possible ignition conditions in a tokamak plasma are reported
z:row.User2: D-3He fusion; radioactive decay; moon; ignition conditions; tokamak plasma; Li

z:row.TitlePrimary: Advances in commerical ICF technology since 1986
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the Eighth Topical Meeting on the Technology of Fusion Energy, Oct 9-13 1988
z:row.Keyword: Nuclear Energy -- Fusion Reactions|Ion Beams|Lasers--Fusion Applications|Lasers, Excimer--Fusion Applications
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Considerable advances have been made in the area of light ion beam fusion through the development of rep ratable drivers (i.e., HERMES-III technology) and diodes (i.e., applied B configuration with renewable Li surfaces). Significant progress in the development of lasers to compress targets has also been made through the KrF Aurora program. The possibility of lowering the cost of glass in the advanced solid state lasers has been given serious consideration. The development of the induced spatial incoherence (ISI) technique to improve the uniformity of the laser beam has allowed physicists and engineers to once again contemplate the use of symmetric illumination. This would reduce the driver energy required to achieve high gains but it also introduces difficulty in the reactor design. Relatively little progress in commercial heavy ion beam drivers has been made over the past few years aside from an indepth study (HIFSA) of the desirable operating regimes to be pursued. Other areas where little progress has been made are conceptual reactor studies, target declassification and specific experimental programs to address commercial ICF reactor technology needs.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Inertial Confinement Fusion; Light Ion Beam Drivers; Heavy Ion Beam Drivers; ICF Drivers; ICF Target Analysis

z:row.TitlePrimary: Mechanical property changes in ion-irradiated metals. Part 1. Ni-Cu alloys
z:row.TitleSecondary: Symposium on Irradiation-Enhanced Materials Science and Engineering - as part of the 1988 World Materials Congress, Sep 25-29 1988
z:row.Keyword: Nickel Copper Alloys -- Radiation Effects|Nickel Metallography--Lattice Defects|Microscopic Examination--Transmission Electron Microscopy
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Metallurgical Transactions A (Physical Metallurgy and Materials Science)
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The effect of radiation-induced dislocation loops on hardness in ion-irradiated Ni-Cu alloys has been studied using a recently developed mechanical properties microprobe (MPM). Well-annealed Ni-10 at. pct Cu and Ni-50 at. pct Cu were irradiated with 14-MeV Ni ions to doses of 20 to 100 displacements per atom (dpa) peak damage (5 to 25 dpa at 1 μm) at 0.45 Tm (485°C and 425°C, respectively). Ultra-low load microindentation hardness measurements and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) were done using cross-sectional techniques. These methods allow for direct hardness measurements, which have been compared to the unirradiated material, of only the small irradiation zone (<3-μm deep). Irradiation induced a high density of dislocation loops, with the size and density of the loops dependent on composition and independent of irradiation conditions. This high dislocation loop density caused a large increase in hardness. A reasonable correlation was found between measured hardness changes and calculated changes based on dislocation loop sizes and densities.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Radiation Hardening; Radiation-Induced Dislocation Loops; Mechanical Property Tests

z:row.TitlePrimary: Effects of 14 MeV nickel ion irradiation on nickel-copper alloys observed in cross-section
z:row.TitleSecondary: Fusion Reactor Materials: Proceedings of the Third International Conference on Fusion Reactor Materials - ICFRM-3, Oct 4-8 1987
z:row.Keyword: Nuclear Reactors, Fusion -- Materials|Nickel Copper Alloys--Defects|Radiation Effects|Microscopic Examination--Transmission Electron Microscopy|Ion Beams
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Two Ni-Cu alloys, Ni-10 at% Cu and Ni-50 at% Cu, as well as pure Ni were irradiated with 14 Mev Ni ions at a homologous temperature of T/ Tm=0.45 up to 100 dpa at the peak damage depth. Most of the samples were pre-injected with 5 Mev oxygen ions at room temperature before Ni ion irradiation. The depth dependence of the ion damage structure was studied by TEM with the samples prepared in cross-section. The results obtained from the Ni-Cu alloys and pure Ni are compared. The mechanism of void suppression in Ni-Cu alloys is discussed in terms of the trapping of vacancies and gas atoms.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Dislocation Loop Density; Void Suppression

z:row.TitlePrimary: RA: A HIGH EFFICIENCY, D-**3He, TANDEM MIRROR FUSION REACTOR
z:row.TitleSecondary: 12th Symposium on Fusion Engineering, Proceedings.
z:row.Keyword: NUCLEAR REACTORS, THERMONUCLEAR -- Research|PLASMAS - Stability|PARTICLE BEAMS|DEUTERIUM|TRITIUM
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The Ra tandem mirror fusion reactor concept features inherent safety, high net plant efficiency, low cost of electricity, low radioactive waste generation, low activation, highly efficient direct conversion, thin radiation shields, and axisymmetric magnets. The safety and environment features are achieved through the use of D/He-3 fuel, while the high efficiency derived from a novel operating mode ICRF (ion cyclotron range-of-frequencies) stabilization allows an axisymmetric magnet set. The Ra concept requires an economic source of He-3, such as recently proposed lunar resources, and a modest physics extension of the requirements for a deuterium-tritium (D-T) tandem mirror reactor. The three critical technology areas for a Ra-mode reactor are the high-energy neutral beams, fueling, and the high-voltage direct converter.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: RA TANDEM MIRROR FUSION REACTOR; ION CYCLOTRON RANGE-OF-FREQUENCIES STABILIZATION; HIGH-ENERGY NEUTRAL BEAMS; REACTOR FUELING; HIGH-VOLTAGE DIRECT CONVERTER

z:row.TitlePrimary: The commercial potential of D-3He fusion reactors
z:row.TitleSecondary: Fusion Engineering Proceedings. 12th Symposium on Fusion Engineering (Cat. No.87CH2507-2), 12-16 Oct. 1987
z:row.TitleTertiary: Fusion Engineering Proceedings. 12th Symposium on Fusion Engineering (Cat. No.87CH2507-2)
z:row.Keyword: deuterium|economics|fusion reactor fuel|fusion reactor theory and design|helium
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Arguments are presented in support of the D-3He nuclear-fueled reaction as the best prospect for generating clear energy in the next century. Although somewhat more difficult to initiate than the DT (deuterium-tritium) reaction, it holds the promise of substantial reduction in radiation hazard, full lifetime reactor components, low decay heat, no T2 breeding, class A waste disposal, and major safety benefits. Because of the potentially higher electrical conversion efficiency, there are also important economic benefits that can be achieved. The 3He can be obtained from the Moon, where conservative estimates indicate that greater than 106 tons of it is loosely bound in the lunar regolith. Estimates are presented for the commercial prospects for the D-3He reaction, a proposed development path, and the benefits such a fusion-based economy can bring
z:row.User2: fusion reactors; radiation hazard; decay heat; class A waste disposal; safety benefits; electrical conversion efficiency; lunar regolith; D-3He

z:row.TitlePrimary: Pulsed stress loading of bare ICF first walls
z:row.TitleSecondary: Workshop on the Relation between Mechanical Properties and Microstructure under Fusion Irradiation Conditions, 27 June-2 July 1985
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor theory and design|plasma confinement
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: There is currently a great deal of uncertainty about the nature and magnitude of mechanical and thermal wall loading anticipated in future Inertial Confinement Fusion (ICF) Facilities. This uncertainty is aggravated by the fact that laser and heavy ion driven reactors will have a much different heat and shock loading than light ion driven systems. The authors' purpose was to quantitatively illustrate the differences that can occur in a laser driven facility versus one in which the targets are compressed by light ion beams
z:row.User2: mechanical wall loading; heat loading; plasma confinement; bare ICF first walls; thermal wall loading; heavy ion driven reactors; shock loading; light ion driven systems; laser driven facility

z:row.Abstract: The authors compare the waste disposal ratings for four structural materials that are proposed for D-T and D-3He reactors. These materials are HT-9, PCA, Tenelon, and a modified HT-9

z:row.TitlePrimary: DESIGN CONSIDERATIONS FOR THE SIRIUS-M ICF MATERIALS TEST FACILITY
z:row.TitleSecondary: 12th Symposium on Fusion Engineering, Proceedings.
z:row.Keyword: NUCLEAR REACTORS, THERMONUCLEAR -- Materials|RADIATION DAMAGE|TOKAMAK DEVICES - Materials|TRITIUM
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: SIRIUS-M is a fusion materials test facility designed to duplicate the time-dependent radiation damage structure unique to inertial confinement fusion (ICF) systems to provide the technology base for an ICF demonstration facility. Single-shell ICF targets with a gain of 13. 4 are symmetrically illuminated by 92 beams of a KrF laser with a total energy of 1 MJ. The impact of tritium breeding and self-sufficiency on the design and economics of SIRIUS-M was examined. The impact of target yield on cavity design and overall costs is examined. It is shown that no economic advantage is gained by using higher yield (100-MJ) targets. Various shielding options were examined to minimize radiation streaming to the laser building through the 92 beam ports. It is shown that this can be achieved using a beam crossover between the last two optical elements.

z:row.Abstract: SIRIUS-M is a fusion materials test facility designed to duplicate the time-dependent radiation damage structure unique to ICF systems in order to provide the technology base necessary for an ICF demonstration facility. Single-shell ICF targets are symmetrically illuminated by 32 beams of a KrF laser with a total laser energy of 1 MJ. z:row.Abstract: Previous studies have shown that a thermally unstable bcc, beta , phase precipitates out in the hcp matrix during irradiation. In this paper, the extent of this phase separation is examined as a function of temperature for low dose ion irradiations.

z:row.TitlePrimary: STABILITY OF VACANCY CLUSTERS IN METALS: II. EFFECT OF OXYGEN AND HELIUM ON VOID FORMATION IN METALS
z:row.Keyword: COPPER AND ALLOYS -- Defects|OXYGEN|HELIUM|RADIATION EFFECTS
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Philosophical Magazine A: Physics of Condensed Matter, Defects and Mechanical Properties
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A model is presented that determines the effect of oxygen and helium on the energies of the common vacancy-cluster configurations, namely the void, dislocation loop and stacking-fault tetrahedron. Representative calculations are given for the case of irradiated copper. The presence of oxygen tends to enhance the stability of the void during nucleation compared to the other vacancy-cluster morphologies by decreasing the void surface energy through a chemisorption process. Helium also tends to stabilize void formation, because of the high binding energy of helium to a vacancy (or cluster of vacancies) compared to a dislocation. Gas concentrations as low as 0. 01 a. p. p. m. He and 5 a. p. p. m. O are predicted to stabilize void formation in copper at certain temperatures. The predictions of the model are in good agreement with the available experimental results.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: STACKING FAULTS; VACANCY CLUSTERS; VOID FORMATION

z:row.TitlePrimary: Design considerations for the SIRIUS-M ICF materials test facility
z:row.TitleSecondary: Fusion Engineering Proceedings. 12th Symposium on Fusion Engineering (Cat. No.87CH2507-2), 12-16 Oct. 1987
z:row.TitleTertiary: Fusion Engineering Proceedings. 12th Symposium on Fusion Engineering (Cat. No.87CH2507-2)
z:row.Keyword: excimer lasers|fusion reactor fuel|materials testing|plasma confinement|plasma production and heating by laser beam|tritium
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Fusion Technol. Inst., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: SIRIUS-M is a fusion materials test facility designed to duplicate the time-dependent radiation damage structure unique to inertial confinement fusion (ICF) systems to provide the technology base for an ICF demonstration facility. Single-shell ICF targets with a gain of 13.4 are symmetrically illuminated by 92 beams of a KrF laser with a total energy of 1 MJ. The impact of tritium breeding and self-sufficiency on the design and economics of SIRIUS-M was examined. The impact of target yield on cavity design and overall costs is examined. It is shown that no economic advantage is gained by using higher yield (100-MJ) targets. Various shielding options were examined to minimize radiation streaming to the laser building through the 92 beam ports. It is shown that this can be achieved using a beam crossover between the last two optical elements
z:row.User2: single-shell targets; SIRIUS-M ICF materials test facility; fusion materials; time-dependent radiation damage structure; inertial confinement fusion; cavity design; shielding; radiation streaming; beam crossover; optical elements; 1 MJ; 100 MJ; KrF laser; 2H

z:row.TitlePrimary: BLANKET AND SHIELD DESIGN OPTIONS FOR ASRA6C - A STELLARATOR POWER REACTOR
z:row.TitleSecondary: 12th Symposium on Fusion Engineering, Proceedings.
z:row.Keyword: NUCLEAR REACTORS, FUSION -- Breeding Blankets|PLASMAS - Confinement
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Fusion Power Associates, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Four blanket options have been considered for ASRA6C. The main differences between the different options lie in the blanket geometry and in the way the blanket inner surface tracks the plasma contour. All blankets utilize liquid Li//1//7Pb//8//3 as the breeder, Be as the multiplier/moderator (one option required no Be), He gas as the coolant, and HT-9 as the structure. A comparison study of the four options was carried out on the basis of neutronics performance, configuration, maintainability, mass utilization, and economics. One option was selected on overall merits and is considered as the reference blanket design for ASRA6C. This blanket has a constant elliptical cross section and uniform thickness. The Be is in pebble-bed form at 55 vol% and is surrounded by 14 vol% LiPb. The blanket is 21-cm thick and yields an overall tritium breeding ratio and energy multiplication of 1. 05 and 1. 2, respectively.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: ASRA6C STELLARATOR; BLANKET DESIGN; SHIELD DESIGN

z:row.TitlePrimary: Fusion materials-adapting to expanding timetables
z:row.TitleSecondary: Fusion Reactor Design and Technology 1986. Proceedings of the Fourth Technical Committee Meeting and Workshop (STI-PUB-754), 26 May-6 June 1986
z:row.TitleTertiary: Fusion Reactor Design and Technology 1986. Proceedings of the Fourth Technical Committee Meeting and Workshop (STI-PUB-754)
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor materials|fusion reactor theory and design|melting|steel|vaporisation
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: There have been considerable advancements in the development of ferritic steels, both from an experimental and theoretical standpoint. More is understood about the steady state swelling regime for austenitic alloys and the microchemical evolution in both types of steels is beginning to yield important insights. Two important areas of progress in nonmetals have been the in-situ-extraction of T2 from solid breeders during irradiation and improved performance of nonmetallic coatings for high heat flux materials. The community also has a better understanding of the melting and vaporization of materials during intense heat pulses
z:row.User2: fusion reactor materials; ferritic steels; steady state swelling regime; austenitic alloys; microchemical evolution; in-situ-extraction; solid breeders; nonmetallic coatings; high heat flux materials; melting; vaporization; intense heat pulses

z:row.TitlePrimary: Ra: a high efficiency, D-3He tandem mirror fusion reactor
z:row.TitleSecondary: Fusion Engineering Proceedings. 12th Symposium on Fusion Engineering (Cat. No.87CH2507-2), 12-16 Oct. 1987
z:row.TitleTertiary: Fusion Engineering Proceedings. 12th Symposium on Fusion Engineering (Cat. No.87CH2507-2)
z:row.Keyword: deuterium|fusion reactor fuel|fusion reactor ignition|fusion reactor safety|fusion reactor theory and design|helium|magnetic mirrors|plasma confinement|plasma heating
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The Ra tandem mirror fusion reactor concept features inherent safety, high net plant efficiency, low cost of electricity, low radioactive waste generation, low activation, highly efficient direct conversion, thin radiation shields, and axisymmetric magnets. The safety and environment features are achieved through the use of D-3He fuel, while the high efficiency derived from a novel operating mode ICRF (ion cyclotron range-of-frequencies) stabilization allows an axisymmetric magnet set. The Ra concept requires an economic source of 3He, such as proposed lunar resources, and a modest physics extension of the requirements for a deuterium-tritium (D-T) tandem mirror reactor. The three critical technology areas for a Ra-mode reactor are the high-energy neutral beams, fueling, and the high-voltage direct converter
z:row.User2: Ra; tandem mirror fusion reactor; safety; plant efficiency; radioactive waste generation; activation; direct conversion; radiation shields; axisymmetric magnets; stabilization; lunar resources; high-energy neutral beams; D-3He

z:row.Abstract: Four blanket options have been considered for ASRA6C. The main differences between the different options lie in the blanket geometry and in the way the blanket inner surface tracks the plasma contour. All blankets utilize liquid Li17Pb83 as the breeder, Be as the multiplier/moderator (one option required no Be), He gas as the coolant, and HT-9 as the structure. A comparison study of the four options was carried out on the basis of neutronics performance, configuration, maintainability, mass utilization, and economics. z:row.TitlePrimary: Measured vaporization and melting of high heat flux materials due to intense heat loads
z:row.TitleSecondary: 11th Symposium on Fusion Engineering. Proceedings (Cat. No.CH2251-7), 18-22 Nov. 1985
z:row.TitleTertiary: 11th Symposium on Fusion Engineering. Proceedings (Cat. No.CH2251-7)
z:row.Keyword: copper|electron beam effects|fusion reactor materials|melting|niobium|stainless steel|vaporisation
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The first wall surfaces of a fusion device will be subjected to intense energy deposition under standard and off-normal operating conditions. To model this phenomenon, the thermal response of copper, niobium. 304 SS and other materials was studied using a well-calibrated electron beam. The tests were from 100 to 600 ms in duration with the surface energy density ranging from 0.2 to 6.2 kJ/cm2. For each material, the net vaporization and average melt layer thickness were measured as a function of absorbed energy density. The experimental results were compared to predictions from an analytical model developed for this thermal problem. General agreement was found for the threshold energy density required for vaporization and melting, as well as the functional dependence of vaporization on energy density. The results indicate that the heat transfer models for the vaporized layer should be refined. Also, some discrepancies between the predicted and measured melt layer at high energy densities suggest improvements are needed in handling the convective mixing within the molten material
z:row.User2: 304 stainless steel; electron beam heating; vaporization; melting; first wall surfaces; melt layer thickness; threshold energy density; 100 to 600 ms; Cu; Nb

z:row.TitlePrimary: LUNAR SOURCE OF **3He FOR COMMERCIAL FUSION POWER
z:row.Keyword: NUCLEAR ENERGY -- Fusion Reactions|HELIUM - Applications|NUCLEAR REACTORS - Fusion
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: An analysis of astrophysical information indicates that the solar wind has deposited an abundant, easily extractable source of **3He onto the surface of the moon. Apollo lunar samples indicate that the moon's surface soil contains approximately 10**9 kg of **3He. If this amount of **3He were to be used in a 50% efficient D-**3He fusion reactor, it would provide 10**7 Gw (electric) multiplied by (times) yr of electrical power. The energy required to extract **3He from the lunar regolith and transport it to earth is calculated to be approximately 2400 GJ/kg. Since the D-**3He reaction produces 6 multiplied by 10**5 GJ of energy per kilogram of **3He, the energy payback ratio is approximately 250.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: LUNAR SURFACE; ISOTOPIC RATIO; FUSION FUELS

z:row.TitlePrimary: THIN BLANKET DESIGN FOR MINIMARS - A COMPACT TANDEM MIRROR FUSION REACTOR
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proc of the Seventh Top Meet on the Technol of Fusion Energy, Jun 15-19 1986
z:row.Keyword: NUCLEAR REACTORS, THERMONUCLEAR -- Breeding Blankets|LITHIUM LEAD ALLOYS - Applications|STEEL - Applications|LIQUID METALS - Applications
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: This paper describes the blanket for the MINIMARS compact tandem mirror fusion power reactor. The blanket, which utilizes HT-9 ferritic steel structure, LiPb breeder, Be multiplier/moderator and He gas cooling, is only 17 cm thick and is backed up by a steel reflector. Helium gas cools the blanket and reflector in series, and the outlet temperature of 575 degree C gives a gross thermal power cycle efficiency of 42. 7%.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: THIN BLANKET DESIGN; MINIMARS; TANDEM MIRROR FUSION REACTOR

z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Materials problems in near term fusion devices tend to be dominated by specialized components. Prevention of radiation damage to superconducting magnet materials (insulators, stabilizers and superconductors) tends to have a large impact on the size hence the cost of fusion devices. Other problems such as impurity control components, breeder materials, and coatings for ICF laser optics will also be the focus of near term materials research.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: Graphite first wall thermal performance in ICF reactor
z:row.TitleSecondary: Second International Conference on Fusion Reactor Materials (ICFRM-2), 13-17 April 1986
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor materials|graphite|ion beam effects|laser beam effects|X-ray effects
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Graphite has been considered as a candidate material for the first wall in ICF reactors. The authors show the thermal performance of the graphite first wall (GFW) in the 0.25 μm laser driven materials test reactor SIRIUS-M. The first wall temperature response due to the X-rays, reflected laser light, and ions that emanate from the 13.4 MJ yield target was calculated for dry GFWs which were either unprotected or gas protected. Evaporation rates and thermal stresses were calculated and minimum radii were chosen for both cases. It was found that the reflected laser light from the target produces the highest temperature rise in the gas protected GFW. If 10% of the laser light is reflected from the target and the reflectivity of graphite is 50%, the maximum thermal stress in the GFW is about 90% of the compressive strength for a 2 m radius cavity. Therefore, the viability of the first wall design depends critically on the laser light reflected from the target, the graphite reflectivity and the strength of the graphite
z:row.User2: fusion reactor materials; first wall thermal performance; ICF reactor; candidate material; graphite first wall; SIRIUS-M; first wall temperature response; X-rays; reflected laser light; ions; thermal stresses; compressive strength; graphite reflectivity; C

z:row.TitlePrimary: LOW-LOAD MICROHARDNESS CHANGES IN 14-Mev NEUTRON IRRADIATED COPPER ALLOYS
z:row.TitleSecondary: Use of Small-Scale Specimens for Testing Irradiated Material.
z:row.Keyword: COPPER AND ALLOYS -- Hardening|NEUTRONS - Irradiation Apparatus|METALLOGRAPHY - Microstructures
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) disks of pure copper and copper alloyed with 5 atom% of either aluminum, manganese, or nickel have been irradiated at 25 degree C with 14-Mev neutrons. Vickers microhardness measurements were obtained as a function of fluence up to a maximum level of 2. 2 multiplied by 10**2**1 n/m**2. Measurements were made at two different values of indenter load (5 and 10 g) in order to facilitate correlations with high-load microhardness data. Estimates of the defect cluster density obtained from 10 g microhardness data are in good agreement with TEM observations obtained on these alloys by other researchers. The measured irradiation-induced microhardness change is about 40% less at an indenter load of 5 g than at an indenter load of 10 g for a fluence of 2 multiplied by 10**2**1 n/m**2. This indicates that irradiation-induced changes in low-load microhardness are dependent on the indenter load; therefore any results which are obtained at low loads should be used with caution.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: LOW-LOAD MICROHARDNESS; TRANSMISSION ELECTRON MICROSCOPY; ANTIVIBRATION TEST STAND; DEFECT CLUSTER DENSITY

z:row.TitlePrimary: GAS EFFECTS ON VOID FORMATION IN 14 MEV NICKEL ION IRRADIATED PURE NICKEL
z:row.TitleSecondary: Fusion React Mater, Proc of the Second Int Conf on Fusion React Mater (ICFRM-2), Apr 13-17 1986
z:row.Keyword: NUCLEAR REACTORS, THERMONUCLEAR -- Materials|NICKEL AND ALLOYS - Radiation Effects|NICKEL METALLOGRAPHY - Microstructures|HELIUM|OXYGEN
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Nickel samples with various helium and oxygen concentrations have been irradiated with 14 Mev Ni ions at 500 degree C to a fluence of 8 multiplied by 10**1**9 ions/m**2 (2 dpa at a 1- mu m depth). Helium atoms with energy varying from 200 to 700 kev were pre-injected at room temperature. In as-received Ni which was cold-worked, a heterogeneous void distribution was observed that could be attributed to the heterogeneous oxygen distribution. In the specimen irradiated after vacuum annealing at 800 degree C for one hour, voids are uniformly distributed. Small amounts of helium (10 appm) enhanced void nucleation in both high (180 appm) and low (75 appm) oxygen content samples, while larger amounts of helium (30 appm) reduced void density in the high oxygen content sample. The void density is lower and void size is larger in low oxygen content samples.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: Lunar source of 3He for commercial fusion power
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor fuel|helium|Moon|nuclear power
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: An analysis of astrophysical information indicates that the solar wind has deposited an abundant, easily extractable source of 3He onto the surface of the moon. Apollo lunar samples indicate that the Moon's surface soil contains ~109 kg of 3He. If this amount of 3He were to be used in a 50% efficient D-3He fusion reactor, it would provide 107 GW(electric)·yr of electrical power. The energy required to extract 3He from the lunar regolith and transport it to Earth is calculated to be ~2400 GJ/kg. Since the D-3He reaction produces 6×105 GJ of energy per kilogram of 3He, the energy payback ratio is ~250. Implications for the commercialization of D-3He fusion reactors and for the development of fusion power are discussed
z:row.User2: commercial fusion power; lunar samples; surface soil; lunar regolith; energy payback ratio; 3He

z:row.TitlePrimary: Preconceptual design of the light ion beam fusion target development facility
z:row.TitleSecondary: 11th Symposium on Fusion Engineering. Proceedings (Cat. No.CH2251-7), 18-22 Nov. 1985
z:row.TitleTertiary: 11th Symposium on Fusion Engineering. Proceedings (Cat. No.CH2251-7)
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor ignition
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Fusion Technol. Inst., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The light-ion fusion target development facility (TDF) will be built in the 1990s, following the anticipated successful operation of PBFA-II, a pulsed power driver system that is expected to drive ICF targets to breakeven conditions. The TDF will be used to test high-yield targets driven by light ion beams. The TDF is the first light ion facility that must be designed to withstand the environment created by high-yield targets. A target chamber with a fatigue lifetime of 15000 shots at 200 MJ and 200 additional shots at 800 MJ using conservative ASME guidelines has been designed. Alternative design features to reduce the induced radioactivity in the chamber are discussed
z:row.User2: light ion beam fusion target development facility; breakeven; high-yield targets; induced radioactivity; 200 MJ; 800 MJ

z:row.TitlePrimary: MICROSTRUCTURAL EVOLUTION IN HELIUM DOPED HT-9 FERRITIC STEEL FOLLOWING 14 MEV NICKEL ION IRRADIATION
z:row.TitleSecondary: Fusion React Mater, Proc of the Second Int Conf on Fusion React Mater (ICFRM-2), Apr 13-17 1986
z:row.Keyword: NUCLEAR REACTORS, THERMONUCLEAR -- Materials|STAINLESS STEEL - Radiation Effects|IRON AND STEEL METALLOGRAPHY - Microstructures|HELIUM|NUCLEAR REACTORS, BREEDER - Materials|NUCLEAR REACTORS, FAST - Materials
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: HT-9 specimens pre-implanted with 100 appm of helium were irradiated with 14 Mev nickel ions up to 60 dpa at temperatures of 400, 500 and 600 degree C. Cavities were observed in the He-doped specimens irradiated at 500 and 600 degree C. The maximum local swelling was 0. 1% in the specimen irradiated at 500 degree C to 60 dpa. There was no difference in precipitate evolution and dislocation loop structure between samples irradiated with and without pre-implanted helium. It is concluded that free gas atoms are essential to the formation of cavities in heavy ion irradiated HT-9, a swelling resistant material.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Microstructural modification of 2 1/4 Cr-1 Mo steel by irradiation with 14 MeV nickel ions
z:row.TitleSecondary: Irradiation Effects Associated with Ion Implantation. Proceedings of the Symposium, 14-15 Oct. 1985

z:row.Keyword: heat treatment|ion beam effects|precipitation|steel|swelling|transmission electron microscope examination of materials|voids (solid)
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Nuclear Instruments & Methods in Physics Research, Section B (Beam Interactions with Materials and Atoms)
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Fusion Technol. Inst., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A ferritic steel (21/4 Cr-1 Mo) was heat-treated to produce three distinct microstructural regions; upper bainite, lower bainite and ferrite. The irradiation response of these different microstructures at 500°C to 14 MeV nickel-ion-irradiation was studied under identical conditions. Damage levels ranged from 80 dpa at the 1 μm depth to 350 dpa at the peak damage depth at 2.1 μm. Irradiated samples were studied in cross section using TEM/AEM thin foil techniques supplemented by precipitate extraction methods. The irradiation drastically changed the type of precipitate in the bainite regions from M3C carbides to radiation-enhanced M2C and M7C3 carbides, and the radiation-induced χ phase was also observed. The radiation-induced G-phase was the only precipitate type formed in the initial ferrite structure. No voids were observed up to 350 dpa in any of the three microstructures unless preinjected helium was present. An average swelling of 0.2% was measured after a dose of 100 dpa in the sample preimplanted to 100 at. p.p.m. helium
z:row.User2: bainite microstructure; ferrite microstructure; Ni ion irradiation; damage levels; TEM; AEM; heat treatment; ferritic steel; precipitate extraction methods; χ phase; G-phase; voids; swelling

z:row.TitlePrimary: EFFECT OF OXYGEN ON VOID STABILITY IN NICKEL AND AUSTENITIC STEEL
z:row.TitleSecondary: Fusion React Mater, Proc of the Second Int Conf on Fusion React Mater (ICFRM-2), Apr 13-17 1986
z:row.Keyword: NUCLEAR REACTORS, THERMONUCLEAR -- Materials|NICKEL AND ALLOYS - Radiation Effects|STAINLESS STEEL - Radiation Effects|NICKEL METALLOGRAPHY - Microstructures|IRON AND STEEL METALLOGRAPHY - Microstructures|OXYGEN
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: This investigation shows that low concentrations of oxygen can achieve decreases in surface energy. The model has been tested by irradiating nickel with 14-Mev Ni ions at 500 degree C. Oxygen was preinjected into one sample to a concentration of 75 appm. The irradiation reached a fluence of 3 multiplied by 10**U 0 Ni-ion/m**2 (28 dpa at the damage peak). This paper focuses on the role of oxygen in void stabilization in nickel and austenitic steel. A model to calculate the required levels of oxygen needed for void formation in copper after ion irradiation is extended to these two metals.

z:row.TitlePrimary: The MINIMARS tandem mirror reactor study
z:row.TitleSecondary: 1986 Annual Meeting of the American Nuclear Society (papers in summary form only received), 15-19 June 1986
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor theory and design
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Transactions of the American Nuclear Society
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Lawrence Livermore Nat. Lab., CA, USA
z:row.Abstract: During 1985-6, Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, in partnership with the Fusion Engineering Design Center of Oak Ridge National Laboratory, the University of Wisconsin, TRW, Grumman Aerospace Corporation, General Dynamics/Convair, Argonne National Laboratory, and the Canadian Fusion Fuels Technology Project, conducted the conceptual design of `MINIMARS', a small commercial tandem mirror reactor with novel octopole end plugs. With a net electric output of 600 MW(e), MINIMARS is expressly designed for short (~4- to 5-yr) construction time, factory-built modules, and a passively safe blanket and thermal cycle. MINIMARS is a small reactor based on the tandem mirror principle that will minimize utility financial risk, thereby providing an attractive alternative to the more conventional large fusion reactor designs encountered to date
