z:row.TitlePrimary: MICROSTRUCTURE OF COPPER FOLLOWING HIGH DOSE 14-Mev Cu ION IRRADIATION
z:row.Keyword: COPPER AND ALLOYS -- Radiation Effects|COPPER METALLOGRAPHY - Microstructures|RADIATION DAMAGE|NUCLEAR REACTORS, THERMONUCLEAR - Materials
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Foils of MARZ grade (99. 998% purity including interstitial impurities) copper were irradiated with 14-Mev Cu ions to peak doses of 40 dpa over the temperature range 100-500 degree C. Examination in a transmission electron microscope revealed that no significant amount of void formation had occurred, in conflict with previous irradiation studies. Instead, a high density of stacking fault tetrahedra (SFT) was observed. The defect cluster density is constant for irradiation temperatures less than equivalent to 200 degree C, and density decreases with irradiation temperature greater than equivalent to 300 degree C. It is postulated that the absence of voids is due to the low oxygen content ( less than 5 wt. ppm). Evidence of displacement damage in the form of black spot clusters (SFT and small dislocation loops) was observed at depths beyond that expected from ion damage range calculations. The discrepancy between damage profiles is most likely due to the use of too large an electronic stopping power value in the calculation, but diffusional spreading effects may also play a role.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: STACKING FAULTS; LATTICE DEFECTS; BLACK SPOTS; VOIDS

z:row.TitlePrimary: Key materials issues for near term fusion reactors
z:row.TitleSecondary: Second International Conference on Fusion Reactor Materials (ICFRM-2), 13-17 April 1986
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor materials|magnetic materials|radiation effects|superconducting magnets|superconducting materials
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Materials problems in near term fusion devices tend not to be dominated by structural alloys, but more by specialized components. Prevention of radiation damage to superconducting magnet materials (insulators, stabilizers, and superconductors) tends to have a large impact on the size, and hence the cost of fusion devices. Other problems such as impurity control components, breeder materials, and coatings for ICF laser optics will also be the focus of near term materials research and sometimes may require solutions which are not relevant for commercial reactors
z:row.User2: materials problems; near term fusion reactors; radiation damage; superconducting magnet materials; insulators; stabilizers; superconductors; impurity control components; breeder materials; coatings; ICF laser optics; commercial reactors

z:row.TitlePrimary: CROSS-SECTION PRECIPITATE EXTRACTION REPLICA TECHNIQUE FOR SURFACE-MODIFIED ALLOYS
z:row.Keyword: MICROSCOPIC EXAMINATION -- Specimen Preparation|STEEL - Radiation Effects|IRON AND STEEL METALLOGRAPHY - Microstructures
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A precipitate extraction technique has been developed that with simple modifications should be applicable to a range of surface-modified alloys. In the example presented, a 2. 2% Cr-1% Mo steel was irradiated with 14-meV nickel ions to produce a 3- mu m-thick surface damage zone. The irradiated specimen was subsequently electroplated with iron, sectioned, and metallographically polished and carbide extraction replicas were prepared by a multistage procedure. Using these techniques, the number density, size morphology, crystallography, and chemistry of precipitates can be studied as a function of depth in the irradiated zone, i. e. versus displacement damage, injected ion effects, preimplanted gases, etc.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: CROSS-SECTION PRECIPITATE EXTRACTION REPLICA TECHNIQUE; SURFACE-MODIFIED ALLOYS; SURFACE MODIFICATION; CARBIDE EXTRACTION REPLICAS; PRECIPITATE MORPHOLOGY

z:row.TitlePrimary: DISORDERING OF CuPd BY 14 MeV COPPER IONS
z:row.TitleSecondary: Fusion React Mater, Proc of the Second Int Conf on Fusion React Mater (ICFRM-2), Apr 13-17 1986
z:row.Keyword: NUCLEAR REACTORS, THERMONUCLEAR -- Materials|COPPER PALLADIUM ALLOYS - Radiation Effects|COPPER METALLOGRAPHY - Order-Disorder
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Initially ordered specimens were irradiated between 296 and 823 K with Mev copper ions to doses between 0. 05 and 3 dpa. At 473 K and below, the ordered structure was destroyed when irradiated at a rate of 10** minus **3 dpa/s to doses as low as 0. 3 dpa. This process was accompanied by a change in the crystal structure from bcc to fcc. Reordering due to rapid vacancy migration dominates over radiation disordering at temperatures above 523 K.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: Thin blanket design for MINIMARS-a compact tandem mirror fusion reactor
z:row.TitleSecondary: 1986 Annual Meeting of the American Nuclear Society (papers in summary form only received), 15-19 June 1986
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor materials|fusion reactor theory and design
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Transactions of the American Nuclear Society
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A primary goal in the MINIMARS fusion power reactor design is to achieve the lowest possible cost of electricity and highest mass utilization while maintaining credibility and passive safety. Because the blanket impacts many components, reducing its thickness while achieving adequate breeding and a high energy multiplication is of prime importance. The authors describe the blanket design and performance
z:row.User2: blanket design; tandem mirror; MINIMARS fusion power reactor; breeding; energy multiplication; performance

z:row.TitlePrimary: First wall and blanket design for a high wall loading compact tokamak power reactor
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the Sixth Topical Meeting on the Technology of Fusion Energy, 3-7 March 1985
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor materials|fusion reactor theory and design|Tokamak devices
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Fusion Technol. Inst., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Among the specific limitations which tend to complicate a compact high wall loading (HWL) tokamak reactor design are high surface and nuclear heating, compactness leading to crowded components, unlikely breeding on the inboard side and frequent first wall/blanket replacement. The authors describe the mechanical, thermal hydraulic and tritium aspects of an improved blanket design for a high β (20%), high wall loading (~10 MW/m2) compact fusion power reactor of 1000 MWth power output
z:row.User2: first wall design; blanket design; high wall loading compact tokamak power reactor; nuclear heating

z:row.TitlePrimary: LOW POWER HIGH WALL LOADING TOKAMAK REACTOR
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proc of the 6th Top Meet on the Technol of Fusion Energy, Mar 3-7 1985
z:row.Keyword: TOKAMAK DEVICES -- Computer Aided Design|NUCLEAR REACTORS, THERMONUCLEAR - Computer Aided Design
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Fusion Technology Inst, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A Summary of a recent design effort for a high wall loading, low power, compact tokamak reactor is presented. The design employs a bean-shaped plasma to reach the second stability regime, where high beta values are attainable. A point design was chosen based on a parameteric survey that was conducted using the Tokamak Systems Code (TSC). The most important parts of that survey are presented here. Investigation of different plasma confinement scaling laws shows that the chosen point design has a reasonable ignition margin.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: TOKAMAK SYSTEMS CODE; BEAN-SHAPED PLASMA; PARAMETER SURVEY; PLASMA CONFINEMENT SCALING

z:row.TitlePrimary: LIGHT ION FUSION TARGET DEVELOPMENT FACILITY PRELIMINARY DESIGN
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proc of the 6th Top Meeting on the Technol of Fusion Energy, Mar 3-7 1985
z:row.Keyword: NUCLEAR REACTORS -- Fusion|ION BEAMS
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Fusion Technology Inst, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The Light Ion Fusion Target Development Facility (TDF) is expected to test approximately ten targets per day having yields in the 50 to 800 MJ range. This large number of high yield microexplosions create design problems in the TDF that are not present in PBFA-I and PBFA-II. The TDF would be the first light ion facility where radioactivity in the target debris and induced in the facility itself constitute a biological hazard. A preliminary conceptual design for the TDF including a reaction chamber, biological shield, target diagnostics package and driver that addresses these and other problems is presented.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: LIGHT IONS; FUSION TARGET DEVELOPMENT; PULSED POWER DRIVER; FIRST WALL

z:row.TitlePrimary: COMPARISON OF DEPTH-DEPENDENT MICROSTRUCTURES OF ION-IRRADIATED TYPE 316 STAINLESS STEELS
z:row.TitleSecondary: Effects of Radiation on Materials: Twelfth International Symposium.
z:row.Keyword: STAINLESS STEEL -- Radiation Effects|ION BEAMS|OXYGEN|MICROSCOPES, ELECTRON|METALLOGRAPHY - Precipitation
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Fusion Engineering Program, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The microstructural response of P7, a high-swelling, 'pure' Type 316 stainless steel and the Magnetic Fusion Engineering (MFE) heat of Type 316 stainless steel were investigated after 14-MeV nickel-ion irradiation. Specimens of the P7 alloy were irradiated to fluences of 3. 3 multiplied by 10**1**6 14-MeV nickel ions/cm**2. Irradiation temperatures ranged from 500 degree C to 650 degree C (0. 45 to 0. 6 TAU //m). In addition, a sample of Type 316 stainless steel was irradiated at 650 degree C (0. 6 TAU //m) to a fluence of 3. 3 multiplied by 10**1**6 14-MeV nickel ions/cm**2. The irradiated specimens were examined in cross section by electron microscopy. The 500 degree C irradiation of the P7 alloy produced a depth-dependent void distribution influenced by the excess interstitial effect of the bombarding ions. The 650 degree C irradiations of the P7 alloy produced a bimodal void distribution at the damage peak. The 650 degree C irradiation of Type 316 stainless steel produced needle-like precipitation in the entire damage region.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: NICKEL IONS; ION IRRADIATION; VOIDS

z:row.TitlePrimary: COMPARISON OF THERMAL AND IRRADIATED BEHAVIOR OF HIGH-STRENGTH, HIGH-CONDUCTIVITY COPPER ALLOYS
z:row.TitleSecondary: Effects of Radiation on Materials: Twelfth International Symposium.
z:row.Keyword: COPPER AND ALLOYS -- Radiation Effects|ION BEAMS|HEAT TREATMENT - Annealing|MICROSCOPES, ELECTRON|RADIATION DAMAGE
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Fusion Engineering Program, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The microstructures of two candidate high-strength, high-electrical conductivity copper alloys (AMZIRC and AMAX-MZC) have been studied after heavy ion irradiation and after thermal annealing. An investigation of the behavior of these alloys following thermal treatment has shown that much of their strength is due to cold-working (high dislocation density). Microhardness measurements revealed that the MZC and AMZIRC copper alloys have a recrystallization temperature of about 475 degree C. Both alloys have been irradiated with 14-MeV copper ions in the temperature range of 400 to 550 degree C (0. 5 to 0. 6 TAU //m). Irradiation was found to enhance dislocation recovery and grain recrystallization processes in both alloys at the lower temperatures. The observed results imply that the MZC and AMZIRC copper alloys may undergo a significant degradation in their mechanical properties when exposed to irradiation at temperatures around 400 degree C.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: IRRADIATION; HIGH CONDUCTIVITY ALLOYS; DISLOCATION; RECRYSTALLIZATION; MICROHARDNESS; VOID SWELLING

z:row.TitlePrimary: PRECIPITATION IN Cu-3. 4 at% Be SOLID SOLUTION DURING HEAVY-ION IRRADIATION: I. INFLUENCE OF IRRADIATION PARAMETERS
z:row.Keyword: COPPER BERYLLIUM ALLOYS -- Radiation Effects|COPPER METALLOGRAPHY - Precipitation|CRYSTALLOGRAPHY
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Dep of Nuclear Engineering, Madison, WI, USA, USA
z:row.Abstract: A study was performed on the microstructure of supersaturated and undersaturated Cu-3. 4 at% Be solid solutions following irradiation with 14 MeV Cu ions. CuBe precipitates, which formed quickly during irradiation at 575-750 K, were characterized quantitatively by transmission electron microscopy (TEM). Precipitate size, number density, and crystallography were determined from specimens irradiated to doses of 0. 25-10 dpa at a dose rate of about 10** minus **3 dpa/s. The fraction of precipitated solute was greatest at 665-695 K, i. e. near the equilibrium solvus temperature and near the temperature where irradiation-induced solute segregation is predicted to be most efficient. Crystallographically, the precipitate platelets shared characteristics of both the gamma -CuBe equilibrium phase and the gamma prime -CuBe intermediate phase. Post-irradiation annealing studies indicated that the fine-particle morphology induced by irradiation was unstable during annealing even at a temperature below the equilibrium solvus.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: ANNEALING; MORPHOLOGY; SEGREGATION

z:row.TitlePrimary: DIFFERENCES BETWEEN NEUTRON DAMAGE IN INERTIAL AND MAGNETIC CONFINEMENT FUSION MATERIALS TEST FACILITIES
z:row.TitleSecondary: Fusion Reactor Materials, Proceedings of the First International Conference.
z:row.Keyword: NUCLEAR REACTORS, FUSION -- Design|NUCLEAR REACTORS - Testing|PLASMAS - Confinement
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: It is a common misconception that the unit of neutron wall loading, the MW/m**2, can be applied equally to the calculation of damage in fusion reactor materials whether it is produced by neutrons from inertially confined fusion (ICF) plasmas or magnetically confined fusion (MCF) plasmas. It is shown that, depending on the geometry of the fusion device, the displacement and/or transmutation rates in any given material could vary by as much as 50-75%. In addition, it is shown that the neutron source spectrum from a MCF plasma is considerably different than that from an ICF plasma and these differences can cause the damage parameters to be as much as 10-15% different for the same MW/m**2 neutron wall loading. The difference in the instantaneous damage rate between ICF and MCF can be as much as a factor of 10**8. With such large differences between ICF and MCF test facilities, it is concluded that great care must be exercised when comparing data between the two confinement approaches.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: MAGNETIC CONFINEMENT FUSION (MCF); INERTIAL CONFINEMENT FUSION (ICF)

z:row.TitlePrimary: PRECIPITATION IN Cu-3. 4 at% Be SOLID SOLUTION DURING HEAVY-ION IRRADIATION: II. DEPTH DEPENDENCE THROUGH THE ION RANGE
z:row.Keyword: COPPER BERYLLIUM ALLOYS -- Radiation Effects|COPPER METALLOGRAPHY - Precipitation
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Dep of Nuclear Engineering, Madison, WI, USA, USA
z:row.Abstract: During irradiation of Cu-3. 4 at% Be solid solutions with 14 MeV ions at temperatures of 575-750 K, high concentrations of CuBe precipitate platelets formed in the 3 mu m deep layer traversed by the energetic ions. Both the displacement-damage dose and the dose-rate increased by an order of magnitude between the free surface and the peak damage depth (2. 3 mu m). To determine the effects of this damage distribution on precipitate distribution, the depth dependence of precipitate characteristics was studied by transmisssion electron microscopy (TEM). Depth profiles of precipitate size and number density are compared with depth profiles of the calculated displacement damage. In all cases, precipitate characteristics varied less with depth than the displacement damage. At lower temperatures, precipitate size increased near the calculated end of range (EOR) and some precipitates formed 0. 5-0. 7 mu m beyond the EOR. At higher temperatures, no precipitates formed beyond the EOR. Crystallographic characteristics did not vary with temperature or depth.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: DEPTH DEPENDENCE

z:row.Abstract: Among the specific limitations which tend to complicate a compact high wall loading (HWL) tokamak reactor design are high surface and nuclear heating, compactness leading to crowded components, unlikely breeding on the inboard side and frequent first wall/blanket replacement. This paper describes the mechanical, thermal hydraulic and tritium aspects of an improved blanket design for a high beta (20%), high wall loading (approximately 10 MW/m**2) compact fusion power reactor of 1000 MW//t//h power output.

z:row.Abstract: A summary of a recent design effort for a high wall loading, low power, compact tokamak reactor is presented. The design employs a bean-shaped plasma to reach the second stability regime, where high beta values are attainable. z:row.TitlePrimary: HETEROGENEOUS VOID FORMATION IN 14 MeV NICKEL-ION IRRADIATED 316 SS
z:row.TitleSecondary: Fusion Reactor Materials, Proceedings of the First International Conference.
z:row.Keyword: STAINLESS STEEL -- Radiation Effects|IRON AND STEEL METALLOGRAPHY - Microstructures|CRYSTALS - Defects|METALLOGRAPHY - Precipitation
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The microstructure of type 316 austenitic stainless steel has been investigated following 14 MeV Ni-ion irradiation to 3. 3 multiplied by 10**1**6 ions/cm**2 (40 dpa peak damage) at temperatures from 450 degree C to 650 degree C. Specimens were prepared in cross section to allow analysis over the entire damage range, and the void parameters, dislocation structure, and precipitation response are reported. Heterogeneous void formation was observed in the absence of gas. The swelling curve from this study has been compared to that derived from helium preinjection work. It was found that helium shifts the peak swelling temperature upwards in excess of 100 degree C for similar damage rates. The precipitation response shows a marked change from small block/rod morphology at 450-550 degree C to Fe//2P thin lathe precipitates at 600-650 degree C. Void formation was detected only for the lower temperature range and was associated with the small block/rod precipitates.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: STAINLESS STEEL TYPE 316; HETEROGENEOUS VOID FORMATION

z:row.TitlePrimary: EFFECT OF HYDROGEN ON VOID PRODUCTION IN NICKEL
z:row.TitleSecondary: Fusion Reactor Materials, Proceedings of the First International Conference.
z:row.Keyword: NICKEL AND ALLOYS -- Radiation Effects|HYDROGEN - Diffusion|CRYSTALS - Defects|NUCLEAR REACTORS, FUSION - Materials
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Samples of high purity nickel were preinjected with hydrogen at 25 degree C and subsequently irradiated with 14 MeV nickel ions at 525 degree C. The resulting microstructure was examined by transmission electron microscopy analysis utilizing a transverse sectioning technique which allowed examination throughout the entire 3 micrometer range of the bombarding ion. It was found that approximately 1-10 appm of hydrogen had a major effect on the production of voids. The hydrogen increased the swelling by a factor of 5 at the 10 appm level over the entire 25 dpa range studied as compared to a similar hydrogen free sample. It is evident from this study that any nickel component in a fusion reactor which is exposed to hydrogen (e. g. , through discharge cleaning) prior to operation of the reactor will be very susceptible to enhanced swelling and possibly reduced mechanical performance.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: DIFFUSE COMPUTER CODE; GAS DRIVEN PERMEATION (GDP); PLASMA DRIVEN PERMEATION (PDP)

z:row.TitlePrimary: MAGNITUDE AND DISTRIBUTION OF THE EXCESS INTERSTITIAL FRACTION DURING HEAVY ION IRRADIATION
z:row.TitleSecondary: Fusion Reactor Materials, Proceedings of the First International Conference.
z:row.Keyword: NICKEL AND ALLOYS -- Radiation Effects|NICKEL METALLOGRAPHY - Microstructures|CRYSTALS - Defects
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: In heavy ion irradiation studies, the injected self-ion has recently been shown to suppress void nucleation in the ion deposition region. Previous theoretical calculations using steady state void nucleation theory have demonstrated that the predicted void number density is sensitive to small changes in the excess interstitial fraction, epsilon //i. In this paper the magnitude and distribution of epsilon //i is examined as a function of depth and incident ion energy for Ni irradiation of Ni. The magnitude of epsilon //i in the ion deposition region increases as the incident ion energy decreases. This increase is especially large below 4 MeV. The use of different electronic stopping power (esp) models in the damage calculations gave differences in epsilon //i of approximately 20% where the LSS esp gave higher results than the Brice esp. For low energy ( less than 5 MeV) ion irradiations there exists no part of the ion range free from the presence of excess interstitials while for the high energy (14 MeV) case the region less than 1. 2 mu m in depth appears to have a negligible epsilon //i value.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: POINT DEFECT LOSS MECHANISM; EXCESS INTERSTITIAL FRACTION DISTRIBUTION

z:row.TitlePrimary: ION IRRADIATION OF HIGH STRENGTH, HIGH CONDUCTIVITY COPPER ALLOYS AT FUSION-RELEVANT TEMPERATURES
z:row.TitleSecondary: Fusion Reactor Materials, Proceedings of the First International Conference.
z:row.Keyword: COPPER AND ALLOYS -- Radiation Effects|COPPER METALLOGRAPHY - Microstructures|NUCLEAR REACTORS, FUSION - Materials|SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETS
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The microstructures of two commercial high strength, high conductivity copper alloys have been examined by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) following heavy ion irradiation. Both alloys were found to be resistant to microstructural changes over the temperature range of 100-250 degree C and peak damage levels of 40 dpa. There is no observable void formation in either of the as-received alloys following single ion irradiation to 40 dpa over a wide temperature range (100-550 degree C).
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: COPPER ALLOY AMZIRC TYPE; COPPER ALLOY AMAX-MZC; VOID FORMATION

z:row.TitlePrimary: CORRELATION OF THE YIELD STRENGTH AND MICROHARDNESS OF HIGH-STRENGTH, HIGH-CONDUCTIVITY COPPER ALLOYS
z:row.TitleSecondary: Fusion Reactor Materials, Proceedings of the First International Conference.
z:row.Keyword: COPPER AND ALLOYS -- Mechanical Properties|COPPER METALLOGRAPHY - Recrystallization|METALS TESTING - Tensile Tests|METALLOGRAPHY - Microstructures
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Vickers microhardness and miniature tensile specimen measurements were made on AMZIRC and AMAX-MZC copper alloys in the cold-worked plus aged and annealed conditions. It was determined that a large portion of the strength of these alloys is due to their cold-worked nature, and this strength is lost when recrystallization occurs. The recrystallization temperature of both alloys is about 475 degree C for a 1 h anneal, and is estimated to be about 320 degree C for a 20 y anneal. A linear correlation between microhardness and yield strength was observed for AMZIRC and AMAX-MZC, namely sigma //y(MPa) equals 3. 0 VHN.

z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the 8th Conference on the Application of Accelerators in Research and Industry, 12-14 Nov. 1984
z:row.TitleTertiary: Nucl. Instrum. Methods Phys. Res. B, Beam Interact. Mater. At. (Netherlands)
z:row.Keyword: foils|interstitials|ion beam effects|ion implantation|nickel|swelling
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Nuclear Instruments & Methods in Physics Research, Section B (Beam Interactions with Materials and Atoms)
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Electropolished foils of high purity nickel were irradiated with 14 MeV nickel ions to produce displacement damage similar to that found in fusion neutron environment. The irradiated samples were prepared for transmission electron microscopy evaluation utilizing a transverse sectioning technique. Results show the formation of a void-free zone at a depth which corresponds to the range of the irradiating ions. The void-free zone increases in size with decreasing irradiation irradiation temperature from 450°C to 400°C. Comparison are made to a current theoretical model relating the effects of injected interstitials to void nucleation rate at similar temperatures
z:row.User2: injected self-interstitials; displacement damage; fusion neutron environment; transmission electron microscopy evaluation; void-free zone; void nucleation rate

z:row.TitlePrimary: WHAT HAVE FUSION REACTOR STUDIES DONE FOR YOU TODAY?
z:row.Keyword: NUCLEAR REACTORS -- Fusion|TOKAMAK DEVICES - Economics|ENVIRONMENTAL ENGINEERING
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: This paper discusses examples of how fusion reactor studies are beneficial to current nuclear programs. Design studies are described which: a) Identify all technologies required for self consistent reactor operation; b) Establish quantitative operating parameters for experimentalists and industry; c) Identify high cost items and long lead research problems; and d) Provide the basis for parametric analysis aimed at moving toward safe, economic reactors.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: Light Ion Fusion Target Development Facility preliminary design
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the Sixth Topical Meeting on the Technology of Fusion Energy, 3-7 March 1985
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor ignition
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Fusion Technol. Inst., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The Light Ion Fusion Target Development Facility (TDF) is expected to test approximately ten targets per day having yields in the 50 to 800 MJ range. This large number of high yield microexplosions creates design problems in the TDF that are not present in PBFA-I and PBFA-II. The TDF would be the first light ion facility where radioactivity in the target debris and induced in the facility itself constitute a biological hazard. It must have a first wall and a target diagnostics package that can survive repeated mechanical and thermal pulses from the target microexplosions. In addition, the repetition rate is much higher than for present day light ion beam drivers. A preliminary conceptual design for the TDF including a reaction chamber, biological shield, target diagnostics package and driver that addresses these and other problems is presented
z:row.User2: Light Ion Fusion Target Development Facility; high yield microexplosions; design problems; target debris; first wall; target diagnostics package; thermal pulses; preliminary conceptual design; reaction chamber; biological shield

z:row.TitlePrimary: Materials testing in TASKA-M
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor theory and design|magnetic mirrors|materials testing
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Fusion Power Associates, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The materials test module design for TASKA-M is presented. A representative 23000 specimen test matrix that utilizes two-thirds of the volume in a single module is described. The remaining test volume can be utilized for high heat flux or surface effects testing as well as dynamic in-situ or component testing. A peak DPA value of 78 can be achieved at the end of the 7.8 full power years of operation. The cumulative volume integrated damage level in the test modules is 4120 dpa.l. TASKA-M, therefore, is most useful for interactive component testing and large specimen qualification testing
z:row.User2: dynamic in-situ testing; magnetic fusion program; magnetic mirrors; materials test module design; TASKA-M; heat flux; surface effects testing; interactive component testing; large specimen qualification testing

z:row.AuthorPrimary: Badger,Bucky Jr|Plumton,Donald L.|Zinkle,Steven J.|Sindelar,Robert L.|Kulcinski,Gerald L.|Dodd,Richard A.|Wolfer,Wilhelm G.
z:row.TitlePrimary: EXPERIMENTAL INVESTIGATION OF THE EFFECT OF INJECTED INTERSTITIALS ON VOID FORMATION
z:row.TitleSecondary: Effects of Radiation on Materials: Twelfth International Symposium.
z:row.Keyword: NICKEL AND ALLOYS -- Radiation Effects|STAINLESS STEEL - Radiation Effects|COPPER AND ALLOYS - Radiation Effects|METAL FOIL - Radiation Effects|MICROSCOPES, ELECTRON
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Fusion Engineering Program, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Pure nickel, a 'pure' Type 316 stainless steel (P7), and two high-strength copper alloys have been irradiated with either 14-MeV nickel or copper ions to a peak damage level of 50 displacements per atom (dpa) ( KAPPA equals 0. 8) at homologous temperatures ranging from 0. 4 to 0. 6 TAU //m. The irradiated foils have been examined in cross section in an electron microscope. The injected interstitial effect on the suppression of the measured void densities in nickel and P7 was found to increase with decreasing temperature. The comparison of these results with nucleation theory shows good qualitative agreement. Quantitative discrepancies are attributed to diffusional spreading of point defects and to the presence of impurity atoms in the matrix.

z:row.TitlePrimary: MICROSTRUCTURAL MODIFICATION OF 21/4 Cr-1 Mo STEEL BY IRRADIATION WITH 14 MeV NICKEL IONS
z:row.TitleSecondary: Irradiat Eff Assoc with Ion Implant -Proc of the Symp, Oct 14-15 1985
z:row.Keyword: STEEL -- Radiation Effects|IRON AND STEEL METALLOGRAPHY - Microstructures|STEEL HEAT TREATMENT
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Nuclear Instruments & Methods in Physics Research, Section B: Beam Interactions with Materials and
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A ferritic steel (21/4 Cr-1 Mo) was heat-treated to produce three distinct microstructural regions; upper bainite, lower bainite and ferrite. The irradiation response of these different microstructures at 500 degree C to 14 MeV nickel-ion-irradiation was studied under identical conditions. Damage levels ranged from 80 dpa at the 1 mu m depth to 350 dpa at the peak damage depth at 2. 1 mu m. Irradiated samples were studied in cross section using TEM/AEM thin foil techniques supplemented by precipitate extraction methods. The irradiation drastically changed the type of precipitate in the bainite regions from M//3C carbides to radiation-enhanced M//2C and M//7C//3 carbides, and the radiation-induced chi phase was also observed.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: IRRADIATION; DISPLACEMENT DAMAGE; PRECIPITATES; PHASE REACTIONS

z:row.TitlePrimary: FUSION REACTOR DESIGN: ON THE ROAD TO COMMERCIALIZATION
z:row.Keyword: NUCLEAR REACTORS, THERMONUCLEAR|NUCLEAR ENGINEERING - Research
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Fusion Engineering Program, Madison, Wis, USA
z:row.Abstract: The worldwide effort in fusion is now approximately 2 billion dollars per year and over 12 billion dollars has been invested since 1951 in developing this energy source for the 21st century. A vital component of the past efforts in fusion research has been the conceptual design activities performed by scientists and engineers around the world. Almost 80 such major designs of Tokamak, Mirror, Laser and Ion Beam Reactors have been published and this article discusses how recent conceptual designs have affected one's perception of future fusion reactor performance.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.Abstract: In this paper the authors focus on the range of some reactor parameters that can be invoked in the design of high wall loading compact tokamak reactors. The tokamak systems code (TSC), version 2, developed at the Fusion Energy Design Center (FEDC), has been used in this work.

z:row.TitlePrimary: ION IRRADIATION OF HIGH STRENGTH, HIGH CONDUCTIVITY COPPER ALLOYS AT FUSION-RELEVANT TEMPERATURES
z:row.TitleSecondary: Fusion React Mater, Proc of the 1st Int Conf, ICFRM-1, Dec 3-6 1984
z:row.Keyword: COPPER AND ALLOYS -- Radiation Effects|NUCLEAR REACTORS, THERMONUCLEAR - Materials|COPPER METALLOGRAPHY - Microstructures
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Fusion Technology Inst, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The microstructures of two commercial high strength, high conductivity copper alloys have been examined by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) following heavy ion irradiation. Both alloys were found to be resistant to microstructural changes over the temperature range of 100-250 degree C and peak damage levels of 40 dpa. There is no observable void formation in either of the as-received alloys following single ion irradiation to 40 dpa over a wide temperature range (100-550 degree C).
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: TRANSMISSION ELECTRON MICROSCOPY (TEM); VOID FORMATION; ION IRRADIATION

z:row.TitlePrimary: CORRELATION OF THE YIELD STRENGTH AND MICROHARDNESS OF HIGH-STRENGTH, HIGH-CONDUCTIVITY COPPER ALLOYS
z:row.TitleSecondary: Fusion React Mater, Proc of the 1st Int Conf, ICFRM-1, Dec 3-6 1984
z:row.Keyword: COPPER AND ALLOYS -- Mechanical Properties|NUCLEAR REACTORS, THERMONUCLEAR - Materials|MATERIALS TESTING - Hardness
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Fusion Technology Inst, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: One of the key material parameters that is used to characterize potential fusion reactor materials is the yield strength. Vickers microhardness and miniature tensile specimen measurements were made on AMZIRC and AMAX-MZC copper alloys in the cold-worked plus aged and annealed conditions. It was determined that a large portion of the strength of these alloys is due to their cold-worked nature, and this strength is lost when recrystallization occurs. The recrystallization temperature of both alloys is about 475 degree C for a 1 h anneal, and is estimated to be about 320 degree C for a 20 anneal. A linear correlation between microhardness and yield strength was observed for AMZIRC and AMAX-MZC.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: VICKERS MICROHARDNESS; TENSILE SPECIMEN MEASUREMENTS; RECRYSTALLIZATION

z:row.TitlePrimary: MAGNITUDE AND DISTRIBUTION OF THE EXCESS INTERSTITIAL FRACTION DURING HEAVY ION IRRADIATION

z:row.Keyword: METALS AND ALLOYS -- Radiation Damage|METALLOGRAPHY - Microstructures|IONS
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Fusion Technology Inst, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: In heavy ion irradiation studies, the injected self-ion has recently been shown to suppress void nucleation in the ion deposition region. Previous theoretical calculations using steady state void nucleation theory have demonstrated that the predicted void number density is sensitive to small changes in the excess interstitial fraction, epsilon //i. In this paper the magnitude and distribution of epsilon //i is examined as a function of depth and incident ion energy for Ni irradiation of Ni.

z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Fusion Engineering Program, Madison, WI, USA, USA
z:row.Abstract: Samples of high purity nickel were preinjected with hydrogen at 25 degree C and subsequently irradiated with 14 Mev nickel ions at 525 degree C. The resulting microstructure was examined by transmission electron microscopy analysis utilizing a transverse sectioning technique which allowed examination throughout the entire 3 micrometer range of the bombarding ion. It was found that approximately 1-10 appm of hydrogen had a major effect on the production of voids.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: SWELLING SUPPRESSION BY INJECTED SELF-INTERSTITIALS
z:row.TitleSecondary: Appl of Accel in Res and Ind '84, Proc of the 8th Int Conf, Nov 12-14 1984
z:row.Keyword: NICKEL AND ALLOYS -- Radiation Damage|MICROSCOPES, ELECTRON
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Nuclear Instruments & Methods in Physics Research, Section B: Beam Interactions with Materials and
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Fusion Engineering Program, Madison, WI, USA, USA
z:row.Abstract: Electropolished foils of high purity nickel were irradiated with 14 Mev nickel ions to produce displacement damage similar to that found in a fusion neutron environment. The irradiated samples were prepared for transmission electron microscopy evaluation utilizing a transverse sectioning technique. Results show the formation of a void-free zone at a depth which corresponds to the range of the irradiating ions. The void-free zone increases in size with decreasing irradiation temperature from 450 degree C to 400 degree C. Comparisons are made to a current theoretical model relating the effects of injected interstitials to void nucleation rate at similar temperatures.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: ELECTROPOLISHED FOILS; DISPLACEMENT DAMAGE; INJECTED INTERSTITIALS; VOID NUCLEATION; TRANSVERSE SECTIONING TECHNIQUE

z:row.TitlePrimary: HETEROGENEOUS VOID FORMATION IN 14 Mev NICKEL-ION IRRADIATED 316 SS
z:row.TitleSecondary: Fusion React Mater, Proc of the 1st Int Conf, ICFRM-1, Dec 3-6 1984

z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Fusion Technology Inst, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Ion irradiation studies are a useful tool to investigate the irradiation response of a material while closely controlling irradiation parameters such as temperature, dose rate, helium injection, etc. In addition, information relevant to basic models of microstructural evolution can be readily generated which may lead to a better understanding of the mechanisms of swelling resistance. The present investigation deals with 14 Mev Ni-ion irradiations of 316 stainless steel. The use of high energy heavy ions and the cross section technique allows data analysis in a damage region free from surface effects and any effects of the injected bombarding ion species. This paper reports the microstructural response of type 316 austenitic stainless steel to a nickel-ion irradiation over the 450-650 degree C temperature range.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: IRRADIATION RESPONSE; VOID PARAMETERS; DISLOCATION STRUCTURE; PRECIPITATION RESPONSE

z:row.TitleSecondary: 1984 Annual Meeting - American Nuclear Society.

z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The authors state that in the past 16 years (1967-1983), there have been at least 79 studies conducted around the world of deuterium-tritium (D-T) fusion, tokamak, mirror, laser, or ion-beam fusion reactors. This paper intends to show that the tokamak reactor studies mainly conducted in the 1973 to 1980 period (87% of all studies performed from 1967 to 1983) have had significant impact on present experimental programs as well as pointing the way for fundamental improvements in the reliability of reactor operation.

z:row.TitlePrimary: CORRELATION OF EXPERIMENTAL AND THEORETICAL RESULTS FOR VAPORIZATION BY SIMULATED DISRUPTION
z:row.TitleSecondary: Plasma Surf Interact in Controlled Fusion Devices, Proc of the 6th Int Conf, May 14-18 1984
z:row.Keyword: METALS AND ALLOYS -- Vaporization|PLASMA DEVICES - Materials|PLASMAS
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Fusion Engineering Program, Madison, WI, USA, USA
z:row.Abstract: Samples of Al, 1100 Al, SS 304, Ni, Mo and TZM were subjected to a simulated plasma disruption produced by a 25 kv electron beam for times of 100 to 500 ms with an energy flux of 0. 5 to 7. 0 kJ/cm**2. The net vaporized thickness was measured as a function of absorbed energy density for experimental results and predicted by theoretical models. Agreement was found for the threshold energy density for vaporization and the functional dependence of vaporization of energy density over a wide range of parameters. The usefulness of electron beam experiments to verify and guide the development of vaporization models for high heat flux component design was shown.

z:row.User2: DISRUPTION; VAPOR SHIELDING; THRESHOLD ENERGY DENSITY

z:row.TitlePrimary: DIFFERENCES BETWEEN NEUTRON DAMAGE IN INERTIAL AND MAGNETIC CONFINEMENT FUSION MATERIALS TEST FACILITIES
z:row.TitleSecondary: Fusion React Mater, Proc of the 1st Int Conf, ICFRM-1, Dec 3-6 1984
z:row.Keyword: BUILDING MATERIALS -- Radiation Damage|NUCLEAR REACTORS, THERMONUCLEAR - Materials
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Nuclear Engineering Dep, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: It is a common misconception that the unit of neutron wall loading, the MW/m**2, can be applied equally to the calculation of damage in fusion reactor materials whether it is produced by neutrons from inertially confined fusion (ICF) plasmas or magnetically confined fusion (MCF) plasmas. It is shown that, depending on the geometry of the fusion device, the displacement and/or transmutation rates in any given material could vary by as much as 50-75%. In addition, it is shown that the neutron source spectrum from a MCF plasma is considerably different than that from an ICF plasma and these differences can cause the damage parameters to be as much as 10-15% different for the same Mw/m**2 neutron wall loading. The difference in the instantaneous damage rate between ICF and MCF can be as much as a factor of 10**8. With such large differences between ICF and MCF test facilities, it is concluded that great care must be exercised when comparing data between the two confinement approaches.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: NEUTRON DAMAGE; MAGNETIC CONFINEMENT FUSION; INERTIAL CONFINEMENT FUSION

z:row.TitlePrimary: High wall loading compact tokamak reactors
z:row.TitleSecondary: 1984 Annual Meeting of the American Nuclear Society, 3-7 June 1984
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor theory and design
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Transactions of the American Nuclear Society
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: There is a strong trend in the fusion community toward the design of compact reactors that produce energy at an economically competitive cost. As was pointed out by Steiner (1983), the reduced reactor system total cost is favored by small plasma size and the reduced reactor system unit cost [$/kW(e)] is favored by high wall loading. The authors focus on the range of some reactor parameters that can be invoked in the design of high wall loading compact tokamak reactors. The tokamak systems code (TSC), version 2, developed at the Fusion Energy Design Center (FEDC), has been used
z:row.User2: compact tokamak reactors; design; reduced reactor system total cost; small plasma size; unit cost; high wall loading; reactor parameters; tokamak systems code

z:row.TitlePrimary: IMPLICATIONS OF USING FERROMAGNETIC STEEL IN MIRROR FUSION REACTORS
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of Topical Conference on Ferritic Alloys for Use in Nuclear Energy Technologies.
z:row.Keyword: FERROMAGNETIC METALS -- Performance|NUCLEAR REACTORS - Fusion|IRON AND STEEL METALLOGRAPHY - Ferrite|STEEL - Magnetic Field Effects
z:row.Publisher: Metallurgical Soc of AIME, Warrendale, PA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Fusion Engineering Program, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The use of ferromagnetic steels for the first wall, the blanket structure, and the coolant circuit in a tandem mirror reactor is analyzed in terms of the magnetic field perturbations, the magnetostatic forces, and the stresses produced by these forces. As an example of magnetostatic forces exerted on ferromagnetic components, the forces on a coolant pipe are evaluated. In order to reduce the number of finite elements required, the pipe is replaced by a slender solid beam of equal material cross section. The forces so obtained are used in the stress analysis for the pipe assuming a clamped support at either end. The magnetostatic forces on the pipe are found to decrease dramatically as the pipe is moved to a greater distance from the mirror axis.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: FERRO MAGNETIC STEEL; TANDEM MIRROR REACTORS; MAGNETOSTATIC FORCE STRESSES; MAGNETIC FIELD PERTURBATION

z:row.TitleSecondary: 1984 Annual Meeting of the American Nuclear Society, 3-7 June 1984
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor fuel|fusion reactor ignition|fusion reactor theory and design|plasma confinement|plasma heating|radiofrequency heating|Tokamak devices
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Transactions of the American Nuclear Society
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Tokamak reactor studies have led to significant improvements in the reliability of reactor operation. These include: (1) the possibility of very long tokamak burn times; (2) use of magnetic divertors and pumped limiters for impurity control; (3) use of RF power for heating and confining fusion fuel; (4) new materials that reduce the radioactivity and enhance the safety feature; (5) analysis of remote maintenance schemes compatible with commercial and test facility design
z:row.User2: fuel heating; fusion fuel confinement; tokamak reactor studies; fusion research programs; reactor operation; tokamak burn times; magnetic divertors; pumped limiters; impurity control; RF power; fusion fuel; safety; remote maintenance; test facility design

z:row.TitlePrimary: ECONOMIC DESIGN OPTIMIZATION OF THE LiPb BLANKET FOR THE MIRROR ADVANCED REACTOR (MARS)
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proc of the Top Meet on the Technol of Fusion Energy, 5th, Apr 26-28 1983
z:row.Keyword: NUCLEAR REACTORS|LITHIUM AND ALLOYS|LEAD AND ALLOYS
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Nuclear Engineering Dep, Madison, Wis, USA
z:row.Abstract: A self-consistent procedure has been established for economic design optimization of the lithium-lead (LiPb) blanket for the MARS tandem mirror reactor. The procedure is necessarily iterative and enables progress in blanket design to be assessed in terms of the minimization of an economic figure of merit F for the complete reactor system. Application of the procedure resulted in a blanket with small ( similar 38 cm) radial thickness, highly enriched (90%) lithium, adequate tritium breeding ratio (1. 14) and a neutron energy multiplication and thermal efficiency approaching those for blankets of considerably larger radial dimensions.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: MIRROR ADVANCED REACTOR STUDY

z:row.TitlePrimary: LIGHT ION FUSION TARGET DEVELOPMENT FACILITY PRE-CONCEPTUAL DESIGN
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proc of the Top Meet on the Technol of Fusion Energy, 5th, Apr 26-28 1983
z:row.Keyword: NUCLEAR REACTORS|NUCLEAR ENERGY - Fusion Reactions|PLASMAS - Confinement
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Nuclear Engineering Dep, Madison, Wis, USA
z:row.Abstract: The light ion fusion target development facility will be used to test high yield ICF targets (50-200 MJ) at the rate of 10 shots per day. The 6 meter diameter cylindrical target chamber is designed as a first wall supported by a structural frame and is capable of withstanding 15,000 full yield shots over a 5 year lifetime. It is made from Al 6061, thus greatly reducing induced activity. The chamber is shielded by a water pool to allow easy access.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: TARGET DEVELOPMENT FACILITY; INERTIAL CONFINEMENT FUSION

z:row.TitlePrimary: EFFECT OF INTERSTITIAL GAS ATOMS ON MICROSTRUCTURAL EVOLUTION IN SELF-ION IRRADIATED NICKEL
z:row.TitleSecondary: Fusion React Mater, Proc of the 3rd Top Meet, Sep 19-22 1983
z:row.Keyword: NICKEL AND ALLOYS -- Radiation Effects|NUCLEAR REACTORS, FUSION - Materials|IONS|METAL FOIL - Radiation Effects|HELIUM|ACCELERATORS - Applications
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Annealed foils of pure nickel were injected with He in concentrations of 100 and 600 atomic parts per million (appm) at room temperature utilizing a 700 kV electrostatic accelerator. Various accelerating potentials over the range 700 kV to 200 kV produced a relatively uniform concentration of interstitial gas atoms extending from a depth of approximately 1. 25 mu m to the surface of the sample. The injected samples were irradiated at temperatures of 525 degree C and 625 degree C with 14 Mev Ni**3** plus ions to a fluence of 1 multiplied by 10**1**6 ions/cm**2 and prepared for transmission electron microscopy evaluation utilizing a transverse sectioning technique. A void-free zone extended from the surface to a depth of 1. 25 mu m. The variation of void number density, average void diameter, and swelling and a function of depth from the surface is presented for each sample. The results are compared with previous studies completed without injected gas atoms.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: INTERSTITIAL GAS ATOMS; TRANSMISSION ELECTRON MICROSCOPY; VOID FORMATION; SWELLING; ELECTROSTATIC ACCELERATORS

z:row.TitleSecondary: Plasma Physics and Controlled Nucelar Fusion Research. Proceedings of the Ninth International Conference, 1-8 Sept. 1982
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor theory and design|stellarators
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Recent encouraging experimental results on stellarators/torsatrons/heliotrons have revived interest in these concepts as possible fusion power reactors. The use of modular coils to generate the stellarator topology has added impetus to this renewed interest. Studies of the modular coil approach to stellarators by UW-Madison and Los Alamos National Laboratory are summarized in this paper
z:row.User2: stellarator fusion power reactor; designs; torsatrons; heliotrons; modular coils

z:row.TitlePrimary: UWTOR-M, a stellarator power reactor utilizing modular coils
z:row.TitleSecondary: Fusion Reactor Design and Technology. Proceedings of the 3rd Technical Committee Meeting and Workshop, 5-16 Oct. 1981
z:row.TitleTertiary: Fusion Reactor Design and Technology. Proceedings of the 3rd Technical Committee Meeting and Workshop
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor theory and design
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A preliminary design of a 5500 MWth modular stellarator power reactor, UWTOR-M, is presented. The authors briefly describe the parametric considerations which led to the UWTOR-M reference design point. The natural stellarator divertor is used for impurity control in conjunction with innovative high performance divertor targets. A unique blanket design is proposed which minimizes tritium inventory in the reactor. Finally, since maintainability is a prime consideration, the authors describe a scheme for servicing the first wall/blanket and other reactor components
z:row.User2: modular coils; preliminary design; stellarator power reactor; UWTOR-M; stellarator divertor; impurity control; divertor targets; blanket design; tritium inventory; servicing

z:row.TitlePrimary: On the role and technological readiness of fast breeders and fusion-fission hybrids in the world nuclear future
z:row.TitleSecondary: Nuclear Technologies in a Sustainable Energy System. Selected Papers from an IIASA Workshop, 25-27 May 1981
z:row.TitleTertiary: Nuclear Technologies in a Sustainable Energy System. Selected Papers from an IIASA Workshop
z:row.Keyword: fission reactors|hybrid reactors|nuclear power
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: This study focuses on the future of hybrids and fast breeders and the possible time windows for their introduction. The technological readiness of both reactors and associated fuel-cycle facilities during these time windows is examined. Four possible options allowing world nuclear demand to be met within the known uranium resource base are identified: (1) breeders alone rapidly introduced in the year 2000; (2) hybrids alone rapidly introduced in 2000; (3) hybrids and breeders simultaneously introduced in 2000 following traditional market-penetration rates; and (4) hybrids and breeders rapidly introduced simultaneously in 2020. It is shown that breeders can be commercially available in 2000 but that the rapid market penetration required in option (1) would require exceptional efforts. Options (2) and (3) are ruled out since it is impossible for hybrids to be commercially available by 2000. An ambitious fusion development plan would allow hybrids to be commercially available by 2020. Option (4) represents a fall-back position in case the introduction of breeders is delayed beyond 2000 or the rapid market penetration rate required in option (1) cannot be achieved
z:row.User2: technological readiness; fast breeders; fusion-fission hybrids; world nuclear future; fuel-cycle facilities

z:row.TitlePrimary: ORDER-DISORDER TRANSFORMATION IN CuPd UNDER 14. 8 Mev NEUTRON AND 1. 8 Mev ELECTRON IRRADIATIONS
z:row.Keyword: COPPER PALLADIUM ALLOYS|NUCLEAR REACTORS, THERMONUCLEAR - Containment Vessels|COPPER METALLOGRAPHY - Order-Disorder
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Nuclear Engineering Dep, Madison, Wis, USA
z:row.Abstract: Ordered and disordered samples were irradiated with fusion neutrons at RTNS-II to a fluence of 1. 8 multiplied by 10**2**1 neutrons/m**2 at 4. 3 K. The irradiation-induced resistivity increase in the ordered sample was about three times as high as that in the disordered one. A replacement to displacement ratio of 24 was obtained. The amount of recovery due to interstitial motion depends on the size difference factor. Samples irradiated under similar conditions do not show any disorder. Results from 1. 8 Mev electron irradiation at 100 K on an ordered sample give a replacement to displacement ratio of 3. 1. Annealing this sample above 300 K resulted in a higher degree of long range order than that obtained prior to irradiation.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: FIRST WALL

z:row.TitlePrimary: MATERIALS ENGINEERING FOR TANDEM MIRROR REACTORS
z:row.TitleSecondary: Fusion React Mater, Proc of the 3rd Top Meet, Sep 19-22 1983
z:row.Keyword: NUCLEAR REACTORS, FUSION -- Materials|HIGH TEMPERATURE ENGINEERING - Materials|PHYSICS - Nuclear|MAGNETIC FIELDS|PLASMAS|ELECTRIC COILS
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Four areas in which unique materials problems appear for mirror reactors are discussed. The necessity to produce very high magnetic fields (20-24 T) requires the design, construction, and operation of normal copper coils in the intense radiation field of the plasma. Use of rapidly changing (50-500 kHz) magnetic fields to reduce the ion density in the transition region also requires Cu coils in the vicinity of the plasma. The collection of ion and electron energy and conversion of that energy into useful power by direct convertor region of tandem mirrors requires operation of very high heat flux components (200-300 W/cm**2). The heating of electrons as well as plasma startup scenarios dictate the extensive use of rf power. These problems are discussed in the light of the recent MARS reactor study.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: MIRROR REACTORS; STELLARATORS; COMPACT TORI; TANDEM MIRROR REACTORS

z:row.TitlePrimary: ANALYSIS OF FORCES ON FERROMAGNETIC COMPONENTS USED IN MAGNETIC FUSION REACTORS

z:row.Keyword: NUCLEAR REACTORS, FUSION -- Cooling Systems|PIPING SYSTEMS - Magnetic Field Effects|PIPE, STEEL - Strain|FERROMAGNETIC METALS - Applications
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The magnetic forces on the coolant pipe of the MARS mirror reactor are calculated and analyzed. The magnitude of these forces is shown to be smaller than those associated with the coolant pressure, but they are not uniform. Such nonuniformity could lead to pipe deformations. It is also shown that the magnetic forces on an equivalent beam with the same material volume provide a reasonable estimate for the total forces on the pipe.

z:row.User2: MARS MIRROR REACTOR; MAGNETIC FORCES; COOLANT PIPES; DEFORMATION; BLANKETS

z:row.TitlePrimary: 14-Mev NEUTRON IRRADIATION OF COPPER ALLOYS
z:row.TitleSecondary: Fusion React Mater, Proc of the 3rd Top Meet, Sep 19-22 1983
z:row.Keyword: COPPER AND ALLOYS -- Radiation Effects|NUCLEAR REACTORS, FUSION - Materials|RADIATION DAMAGE|NEUTRONS|METAL FOIL|MICROSCOPIC EXAMINATION
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Copper and copper alloys with 5 atomic percent of either aluminum, nickel or manganese were irradiated at 25 degree C with 14-Mev neutrons to a fluence of 3 multiplied by 10**2**1 n/m**2. Resistivity, microhardness and electron microscopy were used to characterize the radiation damage. Using a log-normal distribution to describe the defect cluster size distribution, good agreement was found between resistivity estimates of the cluster density and the observed (TEM) density. At least 11% of the defects created during the irradiation escape correlated recombination.

z:row.TitlePrimary: SUMMARY OF PANEL DISCUSSION ON AUSTENITIC STAINLESS STEELS AS FUSION REACTOR STRUCTURAL MATERIALS
z:row.TitleSecondary: Fusion React Mater, Proc of the 3rd Top Meet, Sep 19-22 1983
z:row.Keyword: STAINLESS STEEL -- Radiation Effects|NUCLEAR REACTORS, FUSION - Materials|RADIATION DAMAGE
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A senior panel was asked to address the question of whether austenitic stainless steels are suitable for use in the first wall and blanket structures of commercial fusion power reactors. The discussion showed that there seems to be no problem in using austenitics for near term fusion designs where the neutron fluence is less than 2-3 MW-y/m**2. Extrapolation to the desired 20 MW-y/m**2 or greater values for commercial operation may be made with the Ti modified 316 SS but only with great risk. Other possible alloys to achieve the commercial goals, such as ferritic steels, were suggested but no in-depth analysis was conducted in this forum.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: AUSTENITIC STAINLESS STEELS; FUSION REACTOR STRUCTURAL MATERIALS; PANEL DISCUSSION; FERRITIC STEELS; TITANIUM MODIFIED 316 STAINLESS STEEL

z:row.TitlePrimary: DEPTH DEPENDENT MICROSTRUCTURE IN ION-IRRADIATED 316 TYPE STEELS
z:row.TitleSecondary: Fusion React Mater, Proc of the 3rd Top Meet, Sep 19-22 1983
z:row.Keyword: STAINLESS STEEL -- Radiation Effects|NUCLEAR REACTORS, FUSION - Materials|IRON AND STEEL METALLOGRAPHY - Microstructures|NICKEL AND ALLOYS|IONS|RADIATION DAMAGE
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A cross-section technique was developed and employed to observe 14 Mev nickel-ion damage to Type 316 stainless steels. Solution-quenched 316 SS and the P-7 alloy were irradiated at a flux of 3 multiplied by 10**1**1 Ni ions/cm**2/s to fluences up to 3. 3 multiplied by 10**1**6 Ni ions/cm**2. The heavy-ion irradiation of the P-7 at 650 degree C produced a unique damage state. A near-surface void-free zone was observed. In addition, a bi-modal void distribution was produced at the calculated peak of the damage distribution.

z:row.User2: HEAVY ION IRRADIATION; NICKEL-ION IRRADIATION; SOLUTION-QUENCHED 316 SS; STAINLESS STEEL 316; P-7 ALLOY

z:row.TitlePrimary: TASKA-M, A COMPACT FUSION TECHNOLOGY TEST FACILITY
z:row.TitleSecondary: Fusion React Mater, Part B, Proc of the 3rd Top Meet, Sep 19-22 1983
z:row.Keyword: NUCLEAR REACTORS, FUSION -- Testing|NUCLEAR REACTORS, THERMONUCLEAR - Research|MIRRORS|PLASMAS|PHYSICS - Nuclear|NUCLEAR ENGINEERING
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Fusion Power Associates, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The design of a low power (6. 8 MW) tandem mirror technology test facility is given. The facility is based on physics presently in hand or that should be available by 1985. Technologies employed by TASKA-M are at the mid-1980's level and the device is designed to achieve a peak damage level of approx. 78 dpa in two materials test modules which have a test volume of approx. 170 liters. In addition, two modules are reserved for blanket testing at nominal wall loadings of approx. 1 MW/m**2. The direct cost of TASKA-M is less than 400 million dollars, making it an attractive next step beyond MFTF-B.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: TANDEM MIRROR FUSION TECHNOLOGY; TEST FACILITIES; TASKA-M TEST FACILITY; TOKAMAK TEST REACTOR

z:row.TitleSecondary: Dimensional Stability and Mechanical Behaviour of Irradiated Metals and Alloys, Proceedings of the Conference.

z:row.Publisher: British Nuclear Energy Soc, London, Engl
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Recent progress in fusion research has led to several unique materials requirements. The purpose of this paper is to give the materials scientist a preview of what may be asked of him in the near future as progress in fusion research continues.

z:row.TitlePrimary: EFFECT OF TEMPERATURE ON MAGNETIC FIELD PERTURBATIONS FROM THE FERROMAGNETIC BLANKET IN MARS
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proc of the Top Meet on the Technol of Fusion Energy, 5th, Apr 26-28 1983
z:row.Keyword: NUCLEAR REACTORS|MAGNETIC MATERIALS - Ferromagnetism|COMPUTER SOFTWARE
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Nuclear Engineering Dep, Madison, Wis, USA
z:row.Abstract: The effect of temperature variation in the ferromagnetic blanket of MARS on the induced magnetic field from that blanket is studied. A simple analytical model is used to show that the effect will be mainly at the ends of the blanket. Numerical calculations using the computer program GFUN3D are presented and show that the effect is reasonably small.
