z:row.TitlePrimary: Fusion materials. Adapting to realistic reactor environments
z:row.TitleSecondary: Fusion Reactor Design and Technology. Proceedings of the 3rd Technical Committee Meeting and Workshop, 5-16 Oct. 1981
z:row.TitleTertiary: Fusion Reactor Design and Technology. Proceedings of the 3rd Technical Committee Meeting and Workshop
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor materials|fusion reactor theory and design
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: There has been considerable movement in the fusion materials field since the last International Workshop on Reactor Design (1977). Some of the movement has been forward, e.g. there are much better theoretical descriptions of the melting, vaporization, and electromechanical stresses imposed on first wall material during plasma disruptions. Some of the movement has been `sideways', e.g. the Fusion Materials Irradiation Test Facility (FMIT) now has slipped 3 years in its schedule since the last conference 4 years ago. Finally, there has been very little progress in the fields of pulsed damage simulation for Inertial Confinement Fusion (ICF) systems, definition of the radiation spectra from ICF targets, or the experimental determination of disruption characteristics for magnetic fusion devices. Several new ideas have appeared since 1977 such as the use of low swelling martensitic alloys, the use of a much more favorable breeding material, Pb83Li17, and there have been two major efforts to design materials test facilities: INTOR and TASKA
z:row.User2: reactor environments; fusion materials; melting; vaporization; electromechanical stresses; first wall material; plasma disruptions; pulsed damage simulation; magnetic fusion devices; low swelling martensitic alloys; Pb83Li17; INTOR; TASKA

z:row.TitlePrimary: FIRST WALL MATERIALS SELECTION IN THE LIGHT ION BEAM TARGET DEVELOPMENT FACILITY
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proc of the Top Meet on the Technol of Fusion Energy, 5th, Apr 26-28 1983
z:row.Keyword: NUCLEAR REACTORS|NUCLEAR ENERGY - Fusion|ION BEAMS
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Nuclear Engineering Dep, Madison, Wis, USA
z:row.Abstract: The choice of material for the first wall of the Light Ion Beam Target Development Facility is discussed. Materials considered are Al 6061, Al 5086, 304 stainless steel, HT-9 (ferritic steel), Ti-6Al-4V, Cu-Be C17200, and Cu-Be C17600. The thermal response, mechanical response and induced radioactivity in first walls made of each of these materials are calculated. Minimum thicknesses of these walls are determined and cost estimates are made for the material requirements for each wall. Finally Al 6061 is suggested as the best choice of first wall material.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: FIRST WALL; TARGETS

z:row.TitlePrimary: WITAMIR-I: A tandem mirror power reactor
z:row.TitleSecondary: Fusion Reactor Design and Technology. Proceedings of the 3rd Technical Committee Meeting and Workshop, 5-16 Oct. 1981
z:row.TitleTertiary: Fusion Reactor Design and Technology. Proceedings of the 3rd Technical Committee Meeting and Workshop
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor materials|fusion reactor theory and design
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A conceptual design of a near term commercial tandem mirror power reactor is presented. The basic configuration utilizes Yin-yang minimum B end plugs with inboard thermal barriers, which are pumped by neutral beam injection. The maximum magnetic fields are 6.1 T, 8.1 T and 15 T in the central cell, Yin-yang, and thermal barrier magnets, respectively. The blanket utilizes Pb83Li17 as the coolant and breeder, and HT-9 as the structural material. This configuration yields a high energy multiplication (1.37), a sufficient tritium breeding ratio (1.07) and has a major advantage with respect to maintenance. A single stage direct convertor is used at one end and an electron thermal dump at the other end. The plasma Q is 28 at a fusion power level of 3000 MWth; the net electrical output is 1530 MWe and the overall efficiency is 39%. Cost estimates indicate that WITAMIR-I is competitive with recent tokamak power reactor designs
z:row.User2: 3H breeding; WITAMIR-I; tandem mirror power reactor; design; thermal barriers; neutral beam injection; magnetic fields; blanket; Pb83Li17; coolant; fusion power level; efficiency

z:row.TitlePrimary: The irradiation of high purity and helium doped aluminum with aluminum ions
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the Second Topical Meeting on Fusion Reactor Materials, 9-12 Aug. 1981
z:row.Keyword: aluminium|cavitation|crystal microstructure|dislocations|fusion reactor materials|grain boundaries|impurities|ion beam effects|ion implantation|vacancies (crystal)|voids (solid)
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Cavity formation in high purity aluminum has been explored with the controlled addition of helium gas. Aluminum specimens containing no helium and preinjected helium concentrations of 0.1, 1.0 and 10 at.ppm were irradiated with aluminum ions at 100°C to doses of 0.5 to 26 dpa. The helium preinjection was performed at room temperature (25°C) by a controlled-thickness alpha particle source made from 244Cm oxide. All of the samples containing helium exhibited cavity formation while the aluminum containing no helium showed only vacancy loops and dislocation tangles. The microstructural effects observed were very heterogeneous and scattered in the irradiated aluminum even at the highest damage levels (26 dpa). The cavities were located in the vicinity of grain boundaries but no voids were observed on the grain boundaries themselves. Cavities were observed only in aluminum containing helium
z:row.User2: high purity Al; cavity formation; He doped Al; Al ion irradiation; preinjected He; controlled-thickness alpha particle source; vacancy loops; dislocation tangles; microstructural effects; grain boundaries

z:row.TitlePrimary: DYNAMICS OF MELTING, EVAPORATION, AND RESOLIDIFICATION OF MATERIALS EXPOSED TO PLASMA DISRUPTIONS
z:row.TitleSecondary: Plasma Surf Interact in Controlled Fusion Devices, Proc of the Int Conf, 5th, May 3-7 1982
z:row.Keyword: STAINLESS STEEL|TOKAMAK DEVICES - Erosion|PLASMAS - Thermal Effects
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Fusion Engineering Program, Madison, Wis, USA
z:row.Abstract: First wall components exposed to a high energy flux during a plasma disruption experience a sequence of processes which consists of rapid heating, melting, intense evaporation, resolidification, and cool-down. The dynamics of all these processes has an impact on both the melt layer stability and the thermal stress cycle in the component of the first wall that stays solid. The detailed time history of the temperature distribution is accurately computed by solving a two-moving-boundary problem. The time behavior of the melt layer thickness for both stainless steel and molybdenum is calculated for different disruption energies and different energy fluxes.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: FIRST WALL

z:row.TitlePrimary: SIMULATION OF FUSION FIRST-WALL ENVIRONMENT IN A FISSION REACTOR
z:row.Keyword: NUCLEAR REACTORS, THERMONUCLEAR|NUCLEAR REACTORS - Fission
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wis, Madison, USA
z:row.Abstract: A novel concept to produce a realistic simulation of a fusion first-wall test environment has been proposed recently. This concept takes advantage of the (n, alpha ) reaction in **5**9Ni to produce a high internal helium content in the metal while using the **3He(n,p)T reaction in the gas surrounding the specimen to produce an external heat and particle flux. Models to calculate heat flux, erosion rate, implantation, and damage rate to the walls of the test module are presented. Preliminary results show that a number of important fusion technology issues could be tested experimentally in a fission reactor such as the Engineering Test Reactor.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: TASKA, a fusion engineering test facility for the 1990s
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the Second Topical Meeting on Fusion Reactor Materials, 9-12 Aug. 1981
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor materials
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The preliminary performance of a new Engineering Testing Reactor based on the tandem mirror confinement principle is described. This device, called TASKA, is based on near term (mid 1980s) technology and is designed to test reactor relevant technologies (superconducting magnets, blankets, materials, etc.) for the Demonstration Power Reactor envisioned for the turn of the century. The key operating parameters are a DT power level of 86 MW, a neutron wall loading of 1.5 MW/m2, and an overall tritium breeding ratio of 1.0. Details of the materials testing program reveal that damage levels approaching 100 dpa can be achieved in less than 15 years of irradiation time. TASKA appears to be an attractive, cost effective way of achieving the near term technology testing goals for the world fusion program
z:row.User2: TASKA; fusion engineering test facility; Engineering Testing Reactor; tandem mirror confinement principle; superconducting magnets; blankets; materials; Demonstration Power Reactor; DT power level; neutron wall loading; tritium breeding ratio

z:row.TitlePrimary: A heavy ion beam fusion reactor concept, HIBALL
z:row.TitleSecondary: American Nuclear Society 1982 Winter Meeting, 14-18 Nov. 1982
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactors
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Transactions of the American Nuclear Society
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The generation of electricity from inertially confined fusion reactors (ICFRs) has been studied for more than a decade. Early attention was given to laser-driven systems, but since the mid-1970s, another, more efficient form of driver has been studied. The use of very high energy (several GeV) heavy ion (>200 amu) beams to implode targets containing a deuterium-tritium (DT) mixture has several attractive features. The energy deposition of the particles is classical, the drivers are more efficient (~25% versus <5% for the realistic lasers), and the repetition rate is quite high. The authors describe a system, the Heavy Ion Beam and Lithium-Lead reactor (HIBALL), which uses all these advantages to generate electrical power
z:row.User2: heavy ion driver; DT reactor; heavy ion beam fusion reactor concept; HIBALL; inertially confined fusion reactors; Heavy Ion Beam and Lithium-Lead reactor

z:row.TitlePrimary: The INPORT concept-an improved method to protect ICF reactor first walls
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the Second Topical Meeting on Fusion Reactor Materials, 9-12 Aug. 1981
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor materials
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A method to protect the first metallic walls of ICF reactors from X-rays and target debris has been developed. The concept utilizes porous, flexible tubes of woven C or SiC fibers to contain liquid metals inside the vacuum chamber of an ICF system. These porous tubes allow for ablation and recondensation of liquid metal films. The tubes also moderate the neutron spectra and reduce the displacement and transmutation damage in metallic walls
z:row.User2: INPORT concept; protect ICF reactor first walls; flexible tubes; woven C; SiC fibers; moderate; neutron spectra; displacement; transmutation damage

z:row.TitlePrimary: Production and behavior of point defects in pulsed inertial confinement fusion reactors
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the Second Topical Meeting on Fusion Reactor Materials, 9-12 Aug. 1981
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor materials|fusion reactor theory and design|neutron effects|point defects|steel
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A time-dependent neutronics analysis for the HIBALL reactor is presented. The helium to displacements per atoms (d.p.a.) ratio in the ferritic steel structure is found to be sensitive to neutron spectrum softening. The microstructure calculations show that helium diffusivity is a sensitive function of vacancy accumulation from one pulse to the next. A strong coupling exists between the three components of damage: helium, vacancies, and interstitials. Swelling of the protected ferritic steel first wall of HIBALL is found to be insignificant
z:row.User2: point defects; pulsed inertial confinement fusion reactors; time-dependent neutronics analysis; HIBALL reactor; ferritic steel structure; neutron spectrum softening; helium diffusivity; vacancy accumulation; interstitials

z:row.TitlePrimary: Vaporization and melting of materials in fusion devices
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the Second Topical Meeting on Fusion Reactor Materials, 9-12 Aug. 1981
z:row.Keyword: austenitic stainless steel|evaporation|fusion reactor materials|graphite|melting|molybdenum|plasma-wall interactions
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: High energy fluxes on first wall materials and other components are encountered in magnetic fusion devices, particularly during hard plasma disruptions. A model to predict evaporation and melting is described which contains a formulation of the evaporation kinetics based on transport theory results. The effect of vapor shielding is evaluated under the assumption that plasma ions slowed down in the vapor dissipate their energy in an isotropic manner. Specific results on melting and evaporation are given for 316 SS, Mo, and graphite
z:row.User2: vapour shielding; plasma-wall interactions; austenitic stainless steel; first wall materials; magnetic fusion devices; hard plasma disruptions; melting; evaporation kinetics; transport theory; plasma ions; 316 SS; Mo; graphite

z:row.TitlePrimary: First wall evaporation in inertial confinement fusion reactors utilizing gas protection
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the Second Topical Meeting on Fusion Reactor Materials, 9-12 Aug. 1981
z:row.Keyword: austenitic stainless steel|carbon|evaporation|fusion reactor materials|X-ray effects
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The evaporation of inertial confinement fusion first wall materials from unattenuated pellet X-rays and from radiation emitted by a cavity buffer gas is examined. The low vapor pressure and low X-ray attenuation coefficient of carbon give it a lower erosion rate than stainless steel, despite the larger thermal conductivity of type 316 stainless steel. For the argon buffer gas containing 0.2% Na and pellet yield used in this study, a gas density greater than 0.3 torr (0°C) is required to prevent evaporative erosion of a carbon first wall. A gas density greater than 0.9 torr (0°C) is needed to prevent erosion of a stainless steel wall
z:row.User2: first wall material evaporation; C; Ar buffer gas; inertial confinement fusion reactors; unattenuated pellet X-rays; cavity buffer gas; X-ray attenuation coefficient; type 316 stainless steel; evaporative erosion; gas density

z:row.TitlePrimary: EFFECT OF PREINJECTED GAS ATOMS ON DEPTH DEPENDENT DAMAGE IN SELF-ION IRRADIATED NICKEL
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proc of the IEEE Conf on the Appl of Accel in Res and Ind, 7th, Nov 8-10 1982
z:row.Keyword: NICKEL AND ALLOYS|ACCELERATORS - Applications
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Nuclear Engineering Dep, Madison, Wis, USA
z:row.Abstract: The effect of interstitial gas atoms on cavity formation is studied utilizing a 700-kv accelerator to inject H** plus or He** plus ions into nickel foils. A tandem accelerator then irradiates the foils with 14-Mev nickel to produce displacement damage. Details of the irradiation facilities are presented. Sample preparation and analysis techniques are described. Preliminary results and plans for future experiments are described.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: EFFECTS OF TEMPERATURE AND HELIUM ON VOID FORMATION IN SELF-ION IRRADIATED ALUMINUM
z:row.TitleSecondary: Radiat Damage Anal for Fusion React, Proc of a Symp, Oct 25-28 1982
z:row.Keyword: ALUMINUM AND ALLOYS|NUCLEAR REACTORS, THERMONUCLEAR - Materials|ALUMINUM METALLOGRAPHY - Microstructures
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Dep of Nuclear Engineering, Madison, Wis, USA
z:row.Abstract: High-purity aluminum was irradiated with 9 Mev aluminum ions at several temperatures in the range 25-125 degree C, both with and without pre-injected helium. The aluminum ion irradiation doses ranged from 0. 2 to 20 dpa. Void swelling occurs only when the aluminum contains helium gas, and as little as 0. 1 appm helium is sufficient to nucleate a substantial void population. In the absence of helium, doses of 20 dpa do not result in void formation. The void number density and size are similar to trends observed in nickel and stainless steels. The microstructure often contained heterogeneous distributions of void stringers, suggesting nucleation on dislocations.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: Magnetic considerations of using ferromagnetic steel in mirror fusion reactors
z:row.TitleSecondary: American Nuclear Society 1982 Winter Meeting, 14-18 Nov. 1982
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor materials|martensitic steel|stainless steel
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Transactions of the American Nuclear Society
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The resistance of martensitic stainless steel (HT-9) to neutron radiation damage, which has been confirmed by recent neutron irradiation experiments, makes this steel one of the prime candidate structural alloys to be used in the fusion reactors. However, the fact that this steel is a ferromagnetic material has been regarded as an obstacle for its use in magnetic confinement fusion reactors because of its possible effects on the magnetic field of the device, and the magnetic forces on this material. Chen et al. (1979) have discussed these problems with respect to Tokamak reactors. The authors confine their discussion of the magnetic aspects of using the ferromagnetic martensitic stainless steel (HT-9) to tandem mirror reactors, mainly in the central cell of these reactors, where the highest neutron wall loadings occur
z:row.User2: ferromagnetic steel; mirror fusion reactors; resistance; martensitic stainless steel; HT-9; neutron radiation damage; candidate structural alloys; magnetic confinement fusion reactors; magnetic field; magnetic forces; tandem mirror reactors; highest neutron wall loadings

z:row.TitlePrimary: HELIUM BUBBLE FORMATION IN Cu, Ni AND Cu-Ni ALLOYS
z:row.TitleSecondary: Radiat Damage Anal for Fusion React, Proc of a Symp, Oct 25-28 1982
z:row.Keyword: COPPER AND ALLOYS|NUCLEAR REACTORS, THERMONUCLEAR - Materials|COPPER METALLOGRAPHY - Microstructures|NICKEL METALLOGRAPHY - Microstructures|NICKEL AND ALLOYS - Radiation Damage|COPPER NICKEL ALLOYS
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Dep of Nuclear Engineering, Madison, Wis, USA
z:row.Abstract: The alloys were irradiated with 200-4000 kev**3He ions at a constant homologous temperature of T/T//m equals 0. 65. The samples were analyzed by TEM to compare helium bubble size and density. Visible bubbles were observed in all samples. The pure copper and the Cu-Ni alloys contain similar bubble densities and sizes after irradiation. The pure nickel samples contained helium bubbles of smaller size and higher density.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: Time-dependent neutronics analysis for the HIBALL heavy ion beam fusion reactor
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor theory and design|neutron transport theory|plasma confinement|plasma-wall interactions
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Time-dependent neutronics analysis for the ferritic steel first wall of the HIBALL heavy ion beam fusion reactor conceptual design is presented. Neutron target interactions that lead to spectrum softening and neutron multiplication are accounted for. The time-of-flight (TOF) spread of neutrons within each energy group is considered. Neutron slowing-down in the INPORT first-wall protection system is found to significantly affect the time over which the damage occurs in the first wall. In the case of an unprotected wall, the time spread is determined primarily by the TOF spread. The INPORT concept is found to significantly reduce both average and peak instantaneous rates of displacements per atom, helium production, and energy deposition in the first wall
z:row.User2: time dependent neutronics analysis; neutron target interaction; neutron time of flight spread; neutron slowing down; inertial confinement; HIBALL heavy ion beam fusion reactor; spectrum softening; neutron multiplication; INPORT first-wall protection system; displacements per atom

z:row.Abstract: Time-dependent neutronics analysis for the ferritic steel first wall of the HIBALL heavy ion beam fusion reactor conceptual design is presented. Neutron target interactions that lead to spectrum softening and neutron multiplication are accounted for. The time-of-flight (TOF) spread of neutrons within each energy group is considered. z:row.TitlePrimary: Time-dependent radiation damage to the first wall of a heavy ion beam fusion reactor with porous tube protection
z:row.TitleSecondary: 1981 Annual Meeting of the American Nuclear Society (papers in summary form only received), 7-11 June 1981
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor materials|fusion reactor theory and design
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Transactions of the American Nuclear Society
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: In an inertial confinement fusion reactor the neutron source has a pulsed nature because of the very short burn time over which the fusion reactions occur. Consequently, high instantaneous displacement per atom (dpa) rates are present in an inertial confinement fusion reactor wall and structure. This can lead to significant changes in the microstructure of the first wall material and may result in higher recombination rates, which inhibits void growth and decreases swelling. In this work, the TDA time-dependent discrete ordinates code is used to perform time-dependent neutronics analysis of the HIBALL heavy ion beam (HIB) fusion reactor conceptual design
z:row.User2: radiation damage; first wall; heavy ion beam fusion reactor; porous tube protection; inertial confinement fusion reactor; neutron source; microstructure; neutronics analysis; HIBALL heavy ion beam

z:row.TitlePrimary: UWTOR-M - A CONCEPTUAL DESIGN STUDY OF A MODULAR STELLARATOR POWER REACTOR
z:row.Keyword: NUCLEAR REACTORS, THERMONUCLEAR|PLASMAS - Confinement
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wis, Madison, USA
z:row.Abstract: A preliminary design of a 5500 MW//t//h modular stellarator power reactor, UWTOR-M, is presented. Discrete twisted coils are used in an l equals 3 configuration with maintainability as a prime consideration. The natural stellarator divertor is used for impurity control in conjunction with innovative high performance divertor targets. A unique blanket design is proposed which minimizes the overall tritium inventory in the reactor. Finally, a scheme for maintaining the first wall/blanket and other reactor components is discussed.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: Effect of voids on damage distribution in ion-irradiated nickel
z:row.TitleSecondary: 1981 Annual Meeting of the American Nuclear Society (papers in summary form only received), 7-11 June 1981
z:row.Keyword: fission reactor materials|ion beam effects|Monte Carlo methods|nickel|nuclear engineering computing|voids (solid)
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Transactions of the American Nuclear Society
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Most current theories of the production of defects in solids neglect the evolutionary nature of the microstructure, which, if included, could have an effect on the ultimate spatial distribution of defects. The effects of voids on the range and the damage distributions produced by ions in voided material have been considered by Odette et al. (1974), with no account of the difference between the path length and the projected range. The authors include those effects in the three-dimensional Monte Carlo computer code, HERAD. This code can take into account the effect of inhomogeneities in the material (such as voids) on the range and the spatial damage distribution of the damage. The case considered is for 14-MeV copper ions incident on nickel target
z:row.User2: damage distribution; spatial distribution; path length; HERAD; void effect; 14 MeV Cu ions; three-dimensional Monte Carlo computer code; ion-irradiated Ni

z:row.TitlePrimary: An improved materials testing module for magnetic fusion
z:row.TitleSecondary: 9th Symposium on Engineering Problems of Fusion Research, 26-29 Oct. 1981
z:row.TitleTertiary: 9th Symposium on Engineering Problems of Fusion Research
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor materials|fusion reactor theory and design|materials testing|neutron effects
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The REGAT module, an improved materials testing module for magnetic fusion engineering test facilities, is presented. The damage gradients in the module are reduced by exposing the sides of the module to direct fusion neutrons. A neutronics analysis is presented to assess the effectiveness of using the REGAT module in reducing damage gradients and increasing average damage levels
z:row.User2: radiation damage; materials testing module; magnetic fusion; REGAT module; fusion neutrons; neutronics analysis

z:row.TitlePrimary: UWTOR-M, a conceptual design study of a modular stellarator power reactor
z:row.TitleSecondary: 9th Symposium on Engineering Problems of Fusion Research, 26-29 Oct. 1981
z:row.TitleTertiary: 9th Symposium on Engineering Problems of Fusion Research
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor theory and design
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A preliminary design of a 5500 MWth modular stellarator power reactor, UWTOR-M, is presented. The authors briefly describe the parametric considerations which led to the UWTOR-M reference design point. The design has 18 twisted coils utilizing a multipolarity of 3, a major radius of 24 m, a coil radius of 4.77 m and a plasma aspect ratio of 14. An assumed β of 5% was used. This configuration leads to a rotational transform on the edge of 1.125 giving favourable plasma physics conditions. The natural stellarator divertor is used for impurity control in conjunction with innovative high performance divertor targets. A unique blanket design is proposed which minimizes tritium inventory in the reactor. Finally, since maintainability is a prime consideration, we describe a scheme for servicing the first wall/blanket and other reactor components
z:row.User2: UWTOR-M; design study; modular stellarator power reactor; multipolarity; rotational transform; stellarator divertor; blanket design

z:row.TitlePrimary: FUSION-FISSION HYBRID DESIGN WITH ANALYSIS OF DIRECT ENRICHMENT AND NON-PROLIFERATION FEATURES (THE SOLASE-H STUDY)
z:row.Keyword: NUCLEAR POWER PLANTS|NUCLEAR FUELS - Research
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wis, Madison, USA
z:row.Abstract: In this paper, the overall fuel cycle and the concept of direct enrichment of LWR fuel in a hybrid fission-fusion reactor are discussed. The nuclear analysis and design of the blanket system, inertial confinement fusion performance requirements for hybrid applications, and the integrated SOLASE-H design are presented.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: HYBRID FUSION-FISSION

z:row.TitlePrimary: Irradiation-induced precipitation of Al-Si alloys in the HVEM
z:row.Keyword: aluminium alloys|dislocation loops|electron beam effects|electron microscope examination of materials|precipitation|silicon alloys
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Irradiation-induced defect structures of Al-0.1% Si and Al-0.5% Si alloys after 1 MeV electron irradiation to 0.4 dpa, 3 dpa and 20 dpa in HVEM at 20°C, 110°C and 165°C were analysed. The formation of both vacancy and interstitial loops were observed. It was found that the dislocation loops were decorated with small silicon clusters. Post-irradiation annealing at 100°C caused the dislocation loops to anneal out in the first ten minutes, while the irradiation-induced small silicon clusters dissolved thirty minutes later, at the same time as equilibrium silicon precipitates formed. The growth of vacancy loops is explained by a solute atmosphere model and current models of radiation induced precipitation are examined in the light of the experimental results
z:row.User2: Al-Si alloys; defect structures; 1 MeV electron irradiation; interstitial loops; dislocation loops; annealing; vacancy loops; solute atmosphere model; radiation induced precipitation; high voltage electron microscope; small Si clusters

z:row.TitlePrimary: Comparison of the current analytical and Monte Carlo codes for heavy ion bombardment studies
z:row.TitleSecondary: 1980 Annual Meeting of the American Nuclear Society (papers in summary form only received), 9-12 June 1980
z:row.Keyword: fission reactor materials|physics computing
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Transactions of the American Nuclear Society
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Energetic heavy ion bombardment is currently being used to simulate and study both high fluence fission- and fusion-neutron-related damage in material. It is absolutely essential to accurately know the final spatial distribution of these incident particles and several computer codes have been developed to calculate the range-energy relationship. The most widely used are those based on analytical methods (EDEP-1, Brice) and those based on Monte Carlo simulation (MARLOWE and TRIM). More recently, a faster and simpler code has been developed based on Monte Carlo method (HERAD). Since it is sometimes difficult for the experimenter to choose from the various codes available, the authors have compared the predictions of these codes for a single ion energy (15-MeV copper) in nickel
z:row.User2: EDEP-1; Brice; Monte Carlo simulation; MARLOWE; TRIM; HERAD

z:row.TitlePrimary: FIRST WALL PROTECTION SCHEMES FOR INERTIAL CONFINEMENT FUSION REACTORS
z:row.TitleSecondary: Fusion React Mater, Proc of 1st Top Meet, Jan 29-31 1979
z:row.Keyword: NUCLEAR REACTORS, THERMONUCLEAR|LASERS - Fusion Applications
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wis, Madison
z:row.Abstract: The thermal pulses associated with pellet design can exceed the melting temperature in first walls unless either the chamber size is made unreasonably large or something is done to modify the energy spectra of the pellet debris. Various approaches to absorbing the photons and slowing down the charged particles and neutrons are reviewed. Fluidized walls and low pressure gases show promise.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: FIRST WALL; TARGETS; INERTIAL CONFINEMENT REACTORS; LASER FUSION REACTORS

z:row.TitlePrimary: The effect of liquid-metal protection schemes in inertial confinement fusion reactors
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactors|liquid metals
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The placement of liquid metals (lithium, lead, and a Pb-Li eutectic Pb4Li) between the first wall and the source of neutrons has been considered as a mechanism for extending first wall lifetimes in inertial confinement fusion reactors. This scheme is called the Internal Spectral Shifter and Energy Converter (ISSEC). All three liquid metals have been shown to reduce the radiation damage in the Type 316 stainless-steel structural first wll and thus increase the first wall lifetime
z:row.User2: inertial confinement fusion reactors; liquid metals; first wall lifetimes; Internal Spectral Shifter and Energy Converter; first wall protection

z:row.TitlePrimary: Observations on ordered voids in molybdenum
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor materials|ion beam effects|molybdenum|voids (solid)
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The authors compare their results and other authors' results with the values given by theoretical models and eliminate those models which contradict the data. Molybdenum specimens were irradiated to doses of 1-2 dpa at 700, 800, 900 and 1000°C to study the low dose region. An additional specimen was irradiated to a dose of 19 dpa at 900°C. The present measurements, along with the previous observations, support the existence of a dose threshold between 2 and 5 dpa for void ordering in molybdenum, at temperatures near 0.4 TM (900°C±50) where TM is the absolute melting point
z:row.User2: ordered voids; Mo

z:row.TitlePrimary: VOID SWELLING AND PHASE INSTABILITY IN HEAVY ION IRRADIATED Mo-Zr ALLOY
z:row.TitleSecondary: Fusion React Mater, Proc of 1st Top Meet, Jan 29-31 1979
z:row.Keyword: MOLYBDENUM ZIRCONIUM ALLOYS|MOLYBDENUM METALLOGRAPHY - Microstructures
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wis, Madison
z:row.Abstract: The addition of 7. 5 at. % Zr to Mo causes changes in radiation damage microstructure. An incubation period was required for void nucleation (1. 5 dpa at 900 degree C, 6 dpa at 800 degree C). Total swelling increased at higher temperatures and doses. Dislocation loop formation was promoted early. Solute-defect flux coupling effects were observed.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: EFFECT OF NICKEL AND NITROGEN ON VOID FORMATION IN ION BOMBARDED VANADIUM
z:row.TitleSecondary: Fusion React Mater, Proc of 1st Top Meet, Jan 29-31 1979
z:row.Keyword: VANADIUM AND ALLOYS|VANADIUM METALLOGRAPHY - Microstructures|NUCLEAR REACTORS, THERMONUCLEAR
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wis, Madison
z:row.Abstract: Samples of high purity vanadium have been doped with 1% to 8% nickel or 1% nitrogen and irradiated with 14 MeV Cu ions to dose levels between 1 and 10 dpa at 6 multiplied by 10** minus **4 dpa/sec. The addition of greater than 2% Ni suppressed void formation at temperatures between 350 degree C and 650 degree C. Nitrogen doping reduced void density.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: Energy for the long run. Fission or fusion?
z:row.Keyword: energy resources|fission reactor materials|fission reactor safety|fission reactors|fusion reactors|nuclear power|reviews
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Factors such as hazards, technological costs, and development time are the significant points of comparison for the two most likely long-term energy sources
z:row.User2: fission reactors; fusion reactors; nuclear power

z:row.TitlePrimary: The depth dependent damage profile in nickel irradiated with nickel or copper ions
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor materials|ion beam effects|nickel|swelling|voids (solid)
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: High purity nickel samples have been irradiated with high energy (>14 MeV) heavy ions and the resultant microstructure examined in cross section (i.e., in a plane parallel to the incident ions). The microstructure observed after irradiation with copper ions was not significantly different from that observed after nickel ion irradiated samples. A 100 nm void denuded zone was observed at the front surface in samples irradiated at 525°C, and voids were observed at depths ≈15% greater than the calculated damage curves. An irradiation at 200°C produced a loop lattice structure aligned along {001} with a spacing of ≈40 nm. The steady-state rate equations were formulated and solved to give the depth dependent defect concentrations. The calculated void growths rate was found to qualitatively fit the experimental results. A depth dependent radiation enhanced diffusion model predicted the result that for ion fluences used in this study, the injected copper impurities were confined to the end-of-range region
z:row.User2: depth dependent damage profile; microstructure; void denuded zone; loop lattice structure; depth dependent defect concentrations; void growths rate; depth dependent radiation enhanced diffusion model; irradiated Ni; Ni ions; Cu ions; swelling

z:row.TitlePrimary: Fusion reactors: their challenge to materials scientists
z:row.Keyword: embrittlement|extrapolation|fusion reactor materials|swelling
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nuclear Engng., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The environment of a DT fusion reactor is unlike anything previously experienced in fission reactors and the requirements for first wall materials will be quite severe. Considerable emphasis is placed on characterizing the environment for both magnetically and inertially confined plasmas, focusing on what is known and not known at present. Once the neutron, photon, and charged particle fluxes are determined, the primary damage functions are calculated and it is shown that the displacement rate in inertial confinement fusion reactors and the helium production rate in all DT fusion reactors are sufficiently different to warrant concern over extrapolation from present facilities. The major responses of the first wall to the primary damage state appear in the swelling and embrittlement problems. Observations on potential materials and their operating limits are also made
z:row.User2: DT fusion reactor; first wall materials; inertially confined plasmas; primary damage functions; displacement rate; extrapolation; swelling; embrittlement; materials science; magnetically confined plasmas

z:row.TitlePrimary: Surface damage and thermal effects from transient thermonuclear radiation in inertial confinement fusion reactors
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the Third International Conference on Plasma Surface Interactions in Controlled Fusion Devices, 3-7 April 1978
z:row.Keyword: copper|fusion reactor materials|fusion reactors|ion beam effects
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Fusion Res. Program, Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A general model for transient deposition of thermonuclear radiation has been developed and applied to calculate the response of copper to a reference spectrum typical of laser fusion reactors. At 7 m from a 100 MJ pellet, temperature excursions of approximately 700°C above the ambient temperature are noted for both photons and ions, occurring 0.02 and 2 μs after the thermonuclear burn, respectively. Total displacement rates approach 100 dpa/s at the surface and 500 dpa/s at 1 μm into the copper. Filling the chamber with Ne at 0.5 Torr was found to be sufficient to reduce the temperature excursion in copper by 50% and the dpa rate at the front surface by 25%. The combination of surface temperature transients and ion bombardment was found to increase the sputtering yield by a factor of 4 over ambient temperature values indicating that previous calculations may have seriously underestimated the sputtering damage in laser fusion first walls
z:row.User2: thermal effects; transient thermonuclear radiation; inertial confinement fusion reactors; model; reference spectrum; laser fusion reactors; surface temperature transients; ion bombardment; sputtering yield; laser fusion first walls; Cu

z:row.TitlePrimary: Response of first walls in inertial confinement reactors to thermonuclear radiation
z:row.TitleSecondary: Fusion Reactor Design Concepts, 10-21 Oct. 1977
z:row.Keyword: copper|fusion reactor materials|molybdenum|neutron effects
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A self consistent analysis of the temperature and displacement histories of inertial confinement fusion reactors first walls was performed. The output spectra from two specific pellets were considered: a bare DT pellet and a structured pellet with a mercury shell surrounding the DT fuel. Results for molybdenum and carbon car are presented. Temperature excursions of 2000K and displacement rates as high as 30 dpa/sec are observed at the front surface of the Mo first wall over a period of 10-20 microseconds following each microexplosion
z:row.User2: inertial confinement reactors; thermonuclear radiation; first wall response, Mo; C; temperature transients; fusion pellet output spectra; displacement transients

z:row.TitlePrimary: Progress in materials research for fusion reactors
z:row.TitleSecondary: Fusion Reactor Design Concepts, 10-21 Oct. 1977
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor materials|reviews
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The advance since 1974 in material technology for fusion reactors is discussed in the areas of structural metals, non-metals and radiation environment. Specific examples are given illustrating the degree of progress and the new ideas which have been proposed for their solution. Observations are also made on the use of scarce materials in high-powered reactor designs
z:row.User2: material technology; fusion reactors; structural metals; radiation environment; nonmetals

z:row.TitlePrimary: Swelling of metals during pulsed irradiation
z:row.TitleSecondary: The International Conference on the Properties of Atomic Defects in Metals, 18-22 Oct. 1976
z:row.Keyword: neutron effects|point defects|stainless steel|swelling|voids (solid)
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A model which can treat the growth of voids under pulsed irradiation conditions, is presented. The model is applied to point defect concentration and void radius change in stainless steel 316
z:row.User2: voids; point defect concentration; stainless steel 316; metal swelling; neutron irradiation

z:row.TitlePrimary: Fission and fusion reactors. Critical issues facing the long term deployment of fission and fusion breeder reactors
z:row.Keyword: fission reactors|fusion reactors|nuclear power
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Discusses how the future choice between fission and fusion reactors will be made on the basis of the present knowledge of both systems. Specific advantages and disadvantages of fission and fusion reactors are also outlined and common problems of both discussed
z:row.User2: fusion reactors; fission reactors

z:row.TitlePrimary: Advantages of liquid Pb-Li alloy spectrum shifters in laser fusion reactors
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the ANS Annual Meeting 1978, 18-22 June 1978
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor materials|fusion reactors|lead alloys|liquid alloys|lithium alloys
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Transactions of the American Nuclear Society
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The advantages of using the liquid eutectic (Pb4Li) as an internal spectral shifter and energy converter (ISSEC), as opposed to pure liquid Li or Pb, with respect to first-wall protection, breeding ratio, and energy deposition in the blanket are assessed. Also using an improved displacement damage and PKA spectrum calculation code the possibility of using the existing fission reactor test facilities to test materials to be used in inertial confinement systems with liquid ISSECs is discussed
z:row.User2: liquid Pb-Li alloy; laser fusion reactors; breeding ratio; energy deposition; internal spectral shifter and energy convertor; first wall displacement

z:row.TitlePrimary: The use and performance of graphite and metal ISSECS in Tokamak fusion reactors
z:row.Keyword: fission reactor materials|fusion reactors|graphite|molybdenum|tungsten|vanadium
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Carbon and the metallic elements molybdenum, niobium, vanadium and tungsten have been considered for use as an ISSEC (Internal Spectral Shifter and Energy Converter) in Tokamak fusion reactors. All five materials have been shown to reduce the radiation damage in the 316 SS structural first wall and thus increase the first wall lifetime. On a per unit thickness basis, a tungsten ISSEC is most effective in this regard followed by Mo, Nb, V and carbon ISSECs in decreasing order. If the ISSEC is restricted to transfer its heat to the first structural wall by thermal radiation only, the maximum allowable thickness a carbon ISSEC can have is limited to 9.5 cm, Mo ISSEC to 7.5 cm, Nb to 8.5 cm, V to 4.5 cm and a W ISSEC to 6 cm for a 1 MW/m2 neutronic and 4 W/cm2 surface heat loading. If the ISSEC is cooled by radiation plus conduction, the maximum allowable thickness goes up to 13 cm for C, 10 cm for Mo, 8 cm for V and stays the same for Nb and W. The only ISSEC material to result in an overall reduction in total blanket radioactivity at shutdown is carbon while all of the metallic ISSECs increase the total activity. Among the four metals studied, Mo is considered to be the best material for use as an ISSEC. A definitive choice between a graphite and Mo ISSEC is difficult at this time as both materials have strong positive features; carbon being superior from radioactivity, afterheat, cost and fabricability standpoint, but molybdenum being more effective in reducing the radiation damage in the first structural wall and increasing the energy multiplication in the blanket
z:row.User2: ISSECS; Tokamak fusion reactors; Mo; ISSEC; graphite; V; Nb; W

z:row.TitlePrimary: Heavy ion irradiation of a Ti-6Al-4V alloy
z:row.Keyword: aluminium alloys|crystal microstructure|fusion reactor materials|ion beam effects|precipitation|titanium alloys|vanadium alloys|voids (solid)
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nuclear Engng., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Investigates the microstructure of a promising Ti alloy, Ti-6Al-4V, after high temperature (250-450°C) bombardment with high energy ions. These preliminary investigations were primarily aimed at finding out whether this Ti alloy was susceptible to the formation of voids in a high temperature, neutron environment. A secondary, but almost equally important goal was to define the experimental conditions under which simulation of high damage rates could be performed in Ti alloys. The authors discovered a rather unexpected change in the precipitate microstructure
z:row.User2: microstructure; voids; precipitate microstructure; heavy ion irradiation; damage curve; 250 to 450 degrees C; Ti-Al-V

z:row.TitlePrimary: Heavy-ion irradiation of a Ti-6 Al-4 V alloy
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the ANS Annual Meeting 1978, 18-22 June 1978
z:row.Keyword: aluminium alloys|fission reactor materials|ion beam effects|titanium alloys|vanadium alloys
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Transactions of the American Nuclear Society
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Specimens of Ti-6 Al-4 V were irradiated with 17.5-MeV Cu(4+) ions to a fluence of 1×1016 ions/cm2 at 250, 350, and 450°C. The electron microscope samples were taken at a depth of 1 μm beneath the surface where the material had experienced 1.5 dpa at an average rate of ≃3×10-4 dpa/s. During irradiation the vacuum was maintained at dpa/s. During irradiation the vacuum was maintained at -9 Torr. The most notable result was the absence of voids, once again confirming the general resistance of titanium-base alloys to void damage
z:row.User2: Ti-6 Al-4 V; electron microscope samples; voids; heavy ion irradiation; 17.5 MeV Cu4+ ions

z:row.TitleSecondary: American Nuclear Society Winter Meeting 1977, 27 Nov.-2 Dec. 1977

z:row.Abstract: It is shown how the fully dynamic rate theory (FDRT) can be used to examine the significance of two important irradiation parameters-cascade collapse efficiency and the displacement rate on the swelling of stainless steel over a range of temperatures and fluences
z:row.User2: fully dynamic rate theory; cascade collapse efficiency; displacement rate; swelling; stainless steel; dose rate

z:row.TitlePrimary: A high-performance non-circular Tokamak power reactor design study-UWMAK-III
z:row.TitleSecondary: 6th International Conference on Plasma Physics and Controlled Nuclear Fusion Research, vol.III, 6-13 Oct. 1976
z:row.Keyword: design engineering|fusion reactors|maintenance engineering|nuclear power stations|Tokamak devices
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng., Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Advanced technologies studied include the use of the molybdenum-based alloy, TZM, as the primary structural material, the use of aluminium as the stabilizer and aluminium alloy structure for the NbTi superconducting magnets, and the use of a closed-cycle helium gas turbine power conversion system. New or different design approaches include the study of RF (fast magnetosonic waves) plasma heating, a blanket design where tritium breeding is accomplished only in the outer blanket region, a permanent inner blanket that is basically a hot shield, tritium extraction and recycling processes, and the general design approach to blanket module removal. The maximum module weight is only 42 t. An MHD analysis has determined the non-circular plasma shaped like a characteristic `D' with neutral points on the plasma boundary for a poloidal divertor. The reactor is small (major radius =8.1 m) with a relatively high β (about 9%) and an average neutron wall loading of 2.5 MW.m-2. It is designed to generate 5000 MW(th) during the burn and 1985 MW(e) continuously. The net plant efficiency is about 42%
z:row.User2: Tokamak power reactor design; UWMAK-III; TZM; structural material; gas turbine power conversion; RF; fast magnetosonic waves; plasma heating; blanket design; extraction; recycling; blanket module removal; MHD analysis; poloidal divertor; high performance; noncircular; He closed cycle; T breeding; Mo alloy; Al alloy

z:row.TitlePrimary: Void formation from 200 to 700°C in heavy-ion irradiated vanadium
z:row.TitleSecondary: American Nuclear Society 1977 Annual Meeting. (Extended Abstracts), 12-16 June 1977
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor materials|ion beam effects|transmission electron microscope examination of materials|vanadium|voids (solid)
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Transactions of the American Nuclear Society
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The results of a transmission electron microscope study of high-purity V which has been irradiated with 18 MeV Cu ions at temperatures of 200, 350, 500, and 700°C to a dose of 3.6×15 particles cm-2 are reported. Void microstructure and parameters have been determined, and the void distribution is found to be well developed and homogeneous at all temperatures. It is concluded that voids form readily in heavily-irradiated V, even at the low damage level of 0.5 dpa and damage rate of 10-4 dpa s-1
z:row.User2: transmission electron microscope study; V; 18 MeV; Cu ions; void distribution; damage rate; heavy ion effects; void microstructure; 200 to 700 degrees C

z:row.TitlePrimary: Considerations of the recycle time for radioactive titanium alloy structures
z:row.TitleSecondary: American Nuclear Society Winter Meeting 1977, 27 Nov.-2 Dec. 1977
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor materials|radiation protection|radioactive waste|titanium alloys
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Transactions of the American Nuclear Society
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: There is currently a great deal of interest in the use of titanium and its alloys for the first wall/blanket structure of fusion reactors. This study examines just how long one must contain such radioactive material before it can be safely released to the environment
z:row.User2: recycle time; radioactive Ti alloy structures

z:row.TitlePrimary: Electron irradiation damage in high purity aluminum
z:row.Keyword: aluminium|dislocation loops|electron beam effects|fission reactor materials|interstitials|voids (solid)
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Coll. of Engng., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: An experimental investigation of the defects formed in 99.999% Al following irradiation with 1 MeV electrons up to 10 dpa and at temperatures between 20°C and 200°C has been carried out. The microstructure after irradiation consisted of prismatic and single- and multi-faulted loops, and in excess of 90% of the loops were faulted and interstitial in character. About two-thirds of the prismatic loops were interstitial. In agreement with earlier studies, only an insignificant number of voids were observed, in contrast to nickel and copper which form copious voids when electron irradiated at appropriate temperatures. It is believed that the lack of voids in aluminum is due to a nucleation problem associated with low solubilities in the metal of H2, N2, and O2
z:row.User2: defects; Al; irradiation; 1 MeV electrons; microstructure; interstitial; voids; 20 to 200 degrees C; prismatic faulted loops; single faulted loops; multifaulted loops

z:row.TitlePrimary: The UWMAK-II study: a conceptual design of a helium cooled, solid breeder, Tokamak fusion reactor system
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor ignition|fusion reactor materials|fusion reactors
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. Nuclear Engng., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: UWMAK-II is a conceptual design study of a low β, circular Tokamak fusion power reactor, The aim of the study has been to perform a self-consistent analysis of a probable future fusion power system based on the philosophy that design decision, wherever possible, should be conservative and should be based on present technology. As such, this system will not be the smallest, the leat expensive, or the optimum Tokamak reactor. Rather, it represents a feasible system used to assess the technological problems uncovered and to examine possible solutions. The plasma is designed to generate 5000 MW(th) during a pulse and 1709 MW(e) continuously based upon a burn cycle with a 90 min burn and a 6.5 min rejuvenation period. The plasma carries a current of 14.9 MA and is designed with a double null poloidal divertor for impurity control and particle pumping. In addition, a low Z liner in the form of a carbon curtain is included to eliminate any source of high Z impurities. Plasma heating to ignition involves the use of neutral beam heating for a 10 sec period during which 200 MW of 500 keV deuterium atoms are injected into the plasma. The blanket design employs helium cooling and the solid lithium-bearing compound, lithium aluminate (Li2-Al2O4) for breeding tritium. The structural material is 316 stainless steel and beryllium is used as a neutron multiplier
z:row.User2: double null poloidal divertor; low Z liner; neutral beam heating; blanket design; 316 stainless steel; He cooled solid breeder Tokamak fusion reactor system; C curtain; Be; UWMAK II

z:row.TitlePrimary: Materials resource requirements for D-T fusion power reactors
z:row.TitleSecondary: American Nuclear Society 1975 Winter Meeting. (Summaries), 16-21 Nov. 1975
z:row.Keyword: energy resources|fusion reactors|nuclear reactor materials
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Transactions of the American Nuclear Society
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The environmental assessment of fusion reactors has revealed a materials resource problem which is unique to fusion in relation to its fossil-fuelled and fission competitors. This problem exists because of the relative low-power density of the plasma and the fact that the energy extraction must take place outside the plasma. The complexity of the fusion reactor design stems from many requirements, such as nonmagnetic materials for Tokamaks, mirrors, and theta pinches to special windows, mirrors, and fatigue-resistant alloys in laser reactors. Other special materials requirements come from high-temperature, high-pressure coolants the use of lithium for breeding, and the need for superconductors in some systems. A brief listing of the magnitude of materials problems associated with only three reactor designs, UWMAK-I, UWMAK-II, and the Princeton Plasma Physics Laboratory (PPPL) Tokamak reactor, is presented
z:row.User2: materials resource problem; nonmagnetic materials; Tokamaks; mirrors; theta pinches; windows; mirrors; laser reactors; superconductors; D-T fusion power reactors; fatigue resistant alloys; high temperature high pressure coolants; Li

z:row.Abstract: UWMAK-III is the last of a first generation of conceptual Tokamak power reactor designs carried out at the University of Wisconsin. The basic idea guiding the UWMAK-III study is to assess the long-range potential of Tokamak fusion reactors by carrying out a detailed conceptual design using reasonable extrapolations of present technological capabilities. The thermal power rating has been maintained at 5000 MW(th)
z:row.User2: conceptual Tokamak power reactor designs; thermal power rating; preliminary design; UWMAK III

z:row.TitlePrimary: Reduction of plasma contamination effects and first-wall erosion in fusion devices
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactors
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A mechanism is described by which the benefits of low-Z fusion reactor first walls can be achieved while continuing to take advantage of the high strength and ductility of a metallic vacuum wall. This metallic vacuum wall will also be protected from charged-particle and neutral-atom sputtering thus lowering first-wall erosion rates
z:row.User2: first wall erosion; plasma contamination effects; fusion devices; metallic vacuum wall

z:row.TitlePrimary: Radiation damage by neutrons to materials in DT fusion reactors
z:row.TitleSecondary: 5th International Conference on Plasma Physics and Controlled Nuclear Fusion Research, 11-15 Nov. 1974
z:row.TitleTertiary: 5th International Conference on Plasma Physics and Controlled Nuclear Fusion Research
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactors|neutron effects|nuclear reactor materials|reviews
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A review of the effects of DT neutron damage in fusion reactor structural components and magnets is given. It is shown that the displacement rates in fusion systems are about equal to or less than those of present-day fission reactor facilities but gas production rates are one to two orders of magnitude higher. The effect of neutrons on mechanical properties such as yield strength, ductility, and creep is briefly reviewed and it is noted that very little, if any, direct data exist for 14-MeV-neutron-irradiated metals. Resistivity increases in magnet-stabilizing metals and the reduction in critical properties of superconductors is shown to be minimal and subject to reduction by several design options. The level and decay of induced radioactivity is explored for various metals and levels of ⩾1 Ci per thermal watt are easily achieved at shutdown
z:row.User2: neutrons; materials; DT fusion reactors; review; magnets; displacement rates; fusion systems; mechanical properties; yield strength; ductility; creep; critical properties of superconductors; induced radioactivity; metals; resistivity

z:row.Abstract: The spectral shifter is a nonstructural element which can be made of graphite or three-dimensionally-woven carbon fibers (and containing other materials as appropriate) placed between the plasma and the first structural wall. This results in longer anticipated lifetimes for the structural materials and can significantly reduce radioactivity and afterheat levels. This general class of blanket concepts is referred to as internal spectral shifter and energy converters (ISSEC) concepts
z:row.User2: ISSEC fusion blanket design; spectral shifter; graphite; energy convertors; neutron spectrum; carbon fibres

z:row.TitleSecondary: American Nuclear Society 1975 Annual Meeting. (Summaries only), 9-13 June 1975

z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The advantages of a pure carbon ISSEC (that is, one that does not contain Be or Li compounds) are demonstrated by showing how critical radiation damage parameters such as displacement and gas production rates, along with induced radioactivity levels, can be reduced by this type of neutron spectral shifter
z:row.User2: CTR metallic first walls; neutron spectral shifting; pure carbon ISSEC; critical radiation damage parameters; gas production rates; induced radioactivity levels

z:row.TitlePrimary: Major design features of the conceptual D-T Tokamak power reactor, UWMAK-II
z:row.TitleSecondary: 5th International Conference on Plasma Physics and Controlled Nuclear Fusion Research, 11-15 Nov. 1974
z:row.TitleTertiary: 5th International Conference on Plasma Physics and Controlled Nuclear Fusion Research
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactors|Tokamak devices
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Fusion Technol. Program, Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The conceptual design of a 5000 MW(th)(~1700 MW(e)) helium-cooled Tokamak fusion reactor is presented. The fuel is deuterium and tritium and the structural material is 316 stainless steel. The design has a low aspect ratio (2.6) and low toroidal field on axis (35.7 kG) with 24 extended `D'-shaped superconducting TF coils. A superconducting air core transformer is designed with windings outside TF coils while the vertical field magnets, also superconducting, are inside the extended `Ds'. The plasma operating conditions have been determined using pessimistic scaling laws resulting from trapped-ion instability
z:row.User2: Tokamak power reactor; UWMAK-II; aspect ratio; toroidal field; superconducting air core transformer; scaling laws; He cooling; D-T fusion reactor

z:row.TitlePrimary: Conceptual design of a 5000 MW(th) D-T Tokamak reactor
z:row.TitleSecondary: Workshop on fusion reactor design problems, 29 Jan.-15 Feb. 1974
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactors|Tokamak devices
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The results of self-consistent design effort on a large Tokamak fusion reactor are presented. The reactor fuelled with a deuterium-tritium mixture, operates at 5000 MW(th) and uses 316 stainless steel as a structural material. A compatibility problem between the liquid lithium coolant and the steel limits the operating temperature to 500°C and the electrical output to 1500 MW(E). The ion temperature of the 5-m radius plasma is 11.1 keV and the mean confinement time and fractional burn-up are 14.2 seconds and 7.2% respectively. A double-null poloidal divertor is used to protect the plasma from impurities. Cryogenically stabilized niobium-titanium superconducting magnets are used to provide a 3.82 tesla field on the plasma axis. Neutron and photon transport calculations indicate that the breeding ratio in UWMAK-I is 1.49 and doubling times may be as low as 2-3 months. The tritium leakage is 10.1 Ci/d. The total energy per fusion neutron, including the 3.52-MeV α particle, is calculated to be 20.08 MeV. Radiation embrittlement of the stainless steel limits the first-wall lifetime to two years while swelling and/or surface erosion limits the wall life to about five years. Radioactivity and afterheat calculations reveal that after ten years of operation there will be 1.6×109 Ci of activity and 31 MW(th) of afterheat
z:row.User2: liquid Li coolant; double null poloidal divertor; neutron transport calculation; 5000 MW(th) D-T Tokamak reactor; fusion reactor; 316 stainless steel; structural material; superconducting magnets; photon transport calculations; radiation embrittlement

z:row.TitlePrimary: RADIATION DAMAGE LIMITATIONS IN THE DESIGN OF THE WISCONSIN TOKAMAK FUSION REACTOR
z:row.Keyword: NUCLEAR REACTORS
z:row.Abstract: A detailed analysis of the radiation damage problems to be expected in a specific D-T fueled fusion reactor has been conducted. The system examined is the 5000-MW(th) University of Wisconsin Tokamak reactor (UWMAK), which is constructed of 20% cold-worked Type-316 stainless steel and operated at a maximum temperature of 500C and a neutron wall loading of 1. 25 MW/m**2. The major radiation damage problem appears to be the loss in ductility; that is, the uniform elongation of the Type-316 stainless steel in the UWMAK-I first wall may fall to less than 0. 5% after one to two years of operation. Another serious problem will be the void-induced swelling in the steel. Calculations reveal that the radiation damage problems in the ssuperconducting magnets can be incorporated into the design without difficulty.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: Fusion power-an assessment of its potential impact in the USA
z:row.Keyword: nuclear fusion|nuclear power
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The prospects for harnessing power through the fusion of light nuclei have by turns looked doubtful and hopeful since the first research was conducted some 20 years ago. When might fusion begin to make a significant contribution to electricity generation and what will be the economic and environmental consequences? The author presents possible answers to these questions and also highlights difficulties that could arise in the cost and availability of refractory metals and alloying elements for construction of magnetically-confined plasma reactors
z:row.User2: fusion power; cost; availability; refractory metals; alloying elements; potential impact assessment; magnetically confined plasma reactors

z:row.TitlePrimary: First wall surface problems for a D-T tokamak reactor
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the conference on surface effects in controlled thermonuclear fusion devices and reactors, 10-12 Jan. 1974
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactors|plasma collision processes|sputtering|steel|Tokamak devices
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The effects of deuterium, tritium, helium and neutron bombardment on surface degradation of the first wall of a 5000 MWth D-T reactor have been analyzed. The effects of both sputtering and blistering have been analyzed and the results applied to 316 stainless steel wall operating at temperatures from 300 to 500°C. It has been calculated that the total wall erosion rate is 0.22 mm/year and that 14 MeV neutron sputtering accounts for two thirds of this number. Sputtering from all neutrons results in ≈0.17 mm/year erosion. The calculated erosion rate is 2-3 times that which would be allowable for a 30 year first wall lifetime
z:row.User2: surface degradation; first wall; sputtering; blistering; 316 stainless steel wall; total wall erosion rate; DT Tokamak reactor

z:row.TitlePrimary: A helium-cooled D-T tokamak power plant-UWMAK-II
z:row.TitleSecondary: American Nuclear Society 1974 Winter Meeting. (Summaries), 27-31 Oct. 1974
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactors|Tokamak devices
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Transactions of the American Nuclear Society
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A study of a self-consistent D-T Tokamak reactor has been completed, including the design of a complete power cycle, facilities for handling and containing tritium, facilities for disassembly of radioactive components, environmental analysis, safety assessment, and detailed cost analysis. This reactor has resulted from an optimization of a previous reactor design, UWMAK-I. The present reactor, UWMAK-II, has a power level of 5000 MW(th), a net electrical output of ~1750 MW(e), a nominal plasma radius of 5 m, and an aspect ratio of 2.6. The plasma operated at 16 keV, with a density of 6×1013 sec/cm3, a plasma current of 15 MA, and a confinement time of 5.2 sec. The magnetic field is provided by 24 extended D-shaped, NbTi superconducting toroidal field coils fully stabilized with copper. The field strength is 37 kG on axis
z:row.User2: He cooled plant; D-T Tokamak power plant; design; complete power cycle; UWMAK-II

z:row.Abstract: THe University of Wisconsin Tokamak Fusion Reactor (UWMAK-I) summarized here has been designed with the philosophy that decisions should be based on as little extrapolation of present-day technology capabilities as possible. The goal has been to perform a scoping study in sufficient detail to uncover potential technological problems that may be important as the goal of fusion power comes closer. To this end, authors include in this overview not only a listing of the pertinent design parameters but also a discussion of problem areas examined and proposed solutions as appropriate.

z:row.Keyword: deuterium|fusion reactors|nuclear reactor materials|Tokamak devices|tritium
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Calculations have been performed to assess the effects of fast-neutron-induced transmutation reactions in the blanket region surrounding the plasma in a Tokamak fusion reactor. The production of both stable and radioactive isotopes is considered in three structural materials suggested for CTRs; Type 316 stainless steel, niobium-1% zirconium, and vanadium-20% titanium. The results show that significant changes in the composition of the alloys will be produced along with the generation of large amounts of helium and radio- activity. Of the three alloys studied from the point of view of chemical changes, radioactivity, and afterheat, the vanadium-20% titanium alloy appears to be most favored followed by Type 316 stainless steel and niobium-1% zirconium

z:row.Abstract: Concentrates on the effects of neutron damage to the mechanical properties and dimensional stability of first-wall structural materials. A brief discussion on the particular problems of insulators in &thetas;-pinch reactors and optical windows (and mirrors) for laser devices is included. Discussion of these topics is conveniently broken up into three parts: definition of the problem; status of technology; and required information. One final qualification. It is recognized that it is impossible to completely decouple sputtering, blistering, or even corrosion, from bulk radiation damage. The synergistic effects of all these phenomena must be understood before a comprehensive assessment of CTR materials can be made

z:row.TitlePrimary: Ordered defect structures in irradiated metals
z:row.TitleSecondary: Symposium on Effects of Radiation on Substructure and Mechanical Properties of Metals and Alloys, 25-30 June 1972
z:row.TitleTertiary: Symposium on Effects of Radiation on Substructure and Mechanical Properties of Metals and Alloys
z:row.Keyword: ion beam effects|metals|neutron effects|refractories|voids (solid)
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The production of ordered defect structures in metals by neutron and charged particle bombardment is reviewed. Specific examples of a cubic array of aligned defect clusters are shown in nickel bombarded with 5-MeV nickel ions to 15 displacements per atom (dpa). The effect appears to occur only at temperatures between 280 and 450 C (536 and 842 F). Random defect arrays were found after 40, 180, 525 and 500 C (104, 356, 977, and 932 F) irradiation. Ordered arrays of voids are shown in Ni nickel-irradiated to 300 to 400 dpa at 525 C and in molybdenum, Mo-0.5Ti, titanium-zirconium molybdenum alloy (TZM), columbium, tungsten, and tantalum irradiated with both neutrons and heavy ions. The structure of the voids is consistent with the parent lattice, that is, face centered cubic (fcc) in nickel and body centered cubic (bcc) in the refractory metals. A summary of the information reported to date reveals that the ratio of the lattice parameter of the void superlattice divided by the void radius varies from 5 to 17
z:row.User2: ordered defect structures; irradiated metals; charged particle bombardment; cubic array; aligned defect clusters; random defect arrays; voids; refractory metals; Ni; 5 MeV Ni ion bombarded; Mo; Mo-Ti alloy; neutron bombardment; Ti-Zr-Mo alloy; Nb; W; Ta

z:row.Abstract: A scoping design has been carried out to determine the technological problems associated with the low β Tokamak approach to reactors. This system is envisioned to operate quasi steady state producing about 1000 MW(th) using stainless steel and a wall loading of 0.85 MW/m2. Various system aspects of the design are described including the plasma and its control; a divertor and start-up magnet system; a blanket, shield and heat removal system; toroidal magnet design and limiting stress effects; and an analysis of system hazards

z:row.TitlePrimary: Major technological problems for fusion reactor power stations
z:row.TitleSecondary: International Conference on Nuclear Solutions to World Energy Problems. [Summaries], 12-17 Nov. 1972
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactors
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Transactions of the American Nuclear Society
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: It is now clear that the progress from fusion feasibility experiments to the generation of economical electrical power will be hindered by some of the same obstacles that confronted the development of fission reactors, plus a few problems unique to the fusion process itself. For example, the use of high magnetic field (50 to 150 kG) to contain plasmas will require the development of large bore (5- to 7-m diam) superconducting magnets. The imposition of high magnetic fields on the blanket will also complicate the removal of heat with liquid metals. The high-energy neutrons (14.1 MeV) produced by the D-T reaction will result in hydrogen and helium production rates in metals that are a factor of 10 to 100 higher than those typically found in fission reactors. These gases, especially helium, are known to embrittle metals; therefore, methods will have to be found to cope with brittle structural members. The fusion reactor, like many other new technologies before it, faces an impressive list of problems that must be solved before commercial power generation is achieved. However, none of the problems appears insurmountable at this time
z:row.User2: technological problems; fusion reactor power stations; fusion feasibility experiments; high magnetic fields; superconducting magnets; removal of heat; hydrogen; helium; embrittle; brittle structural members; plasma heating; plasma contamination; wall erosion rates; pumping losses
